(08:45:14)<konijn_nyt>		} else if (message.startsWith("roll") ) {
(08:45:16)<konijn_nyt>			//Does the text after "roll " ( hence 5 chars ) match the regular expression for a dice roll like 3d6 ?
(08:45:19)<konijn_nyt>			Matcher matcher = Pattern.compile( "([0-9]{1,2})?(d|D)([0-9]{1,3})((\\+|-)([0-9]{1,3}))?" ).matcher( message.substring( 5 ) );
(08:45:22)<konijn_nyt>			//group methods only work if you first call the method matches
(08:45:26)<konijn_nyt>			if( matcher.matches() ){
(08:45:29)<konijn_nyt>				//The first dice can be missing, in that case we assume 1 for dice count
(08:45:32)<konijn_nyt>				int diceCount = matcher.group(1)==null?1:Integer.parseInt( matcher.group(1) );
(08:45:34)<konijn_nyt>				int diceSides = Integer.parseInt( matcher.group(3) );
(08:45:37)<konijn_nyt>				int result =0;
(08:45:40)<konijn_nyt>				for( int i = 0 ; i < diceCount ; i++ ){
(08:45:43)<konijn_nyt>					result = result + (int)( Math.random() * diceSides ) + 1;
(08:45:46)<konijn_nyt>				}
(08:45:49)<konijn_nyt>				//Hack, if diceSides is 0, the result should be 0
(08:45:52)<konijn_nyt>				if (diceSides==0)  result = 0;
(08:45:55)<konijn_nyt>				writeMessage( channel , String.valueOf( result ) );
(08:45:58)<konijn_nyt>			}

(11:47:02)<joe6pack>it happens when you leave the function scope and the stack is trashed
(11:47:10)<joe6pack>give me a min i'll write an example
(11:50:39)<joe6pack>char ** some_function(){
(11:50:43)<joe6pack>	char** str= malloc(sizeof(char)*50 );
(11:50:43)<joe6pack>	*str="1234\n";
(11:50:43)<joe6pack>	return str;
(11:50:43)<joe6pack>}
(11:50:51)<joe6pack>main(){ printf(*some_function());
(11:50:52)<joe6pack>}
(11:51:33)<joe6pack>that way the content of the string is not trashed after you leave the function some_function()
(11:52:29)<Numeron>i cant define anything in the global scope without it being static though can i?
(11:52:43)<joe6pack>?
(11:53:10)<joe6pack>of course you can define pointers in the global scope
(11:53:48)<joe6pack>you just don't allocate the memory in the global scope

(07:19:24)<TeeEmCee>does a game need permadeath to be a RL?
(07:19:50)<TeeEmCee>I think it's not totally necessary
(07:20:38)<TeeEmCee>there are often rl's on At Play with some sort of 'continue from last town with lost equipment' feature
(07:52:13)<Numeron>i dont think so. for me a roguelike is simply rogue-like. if its like rogue in some way then it passes the bar, but it doesnt have to be in every way
(07:52:52)<Numeron>permadeath is a good idea though
(07:53:04)<TeeEmCee>normally
(07:53:20)<TeeEmCee>well, for a traditional roguelike anyway
(07:53:21)<TeeEmCee>f
(07:53:37)<TeeEmCee>don't know if you count crown of the forest as a rl
(07:54:06)<Numeron>i count it as one. it has rpg features in a turn based ascii environment
(07:54:27)<TeeEmCee>but such a game shows permadeath can be replaced with other gameplay
(07:56:18)<Numeron>it does, but does that then exclude it from being a rl? my definition of a rl is very very loose
(07:56:53)<Numeron>is a rl without potions a rl?
(07:57:12)<TeeEmCee>definitely
(07:57:29)<TeeEmCee>that's easy
(07:57:45)<Numeron>then why is a rl without permadeath not a rl? permadeath is a feature jsut like potions are a feature, removing one doesnt make it any less rl
(07:57:56)<TeeEmCee>but it's possible to stray waaaay away from rogue, and still present the game the same
(07:58:16)<TeeEmCee>it seems like people care more about presentation than gameplay in their definitions
(07:58:56)<TeeEmCee>like you mentioned ascii
(08:00:28)<Numeron>well in crown, you run around, turnbased inside cells (ascii isnt important, since there are rls with tiles) casting spells, buying potions pwning other creatures, thats pretty much what a rl is: it jsut doesnt have down stairs and a different win condition
(08:01:39)<Numeron>and thats all gameplay
(08:01:58)<TeeEmCee>yeah, crown is still fairly close to rogue despite being a totally different idea
(08:02:10)<Numeron>therefore it is rogue-like

(08:02:23)<TeeEmCee>yep

(11:28:51)<oeb>Ok, first off in the book they were vampires rather than zombies.
(11:28:58)<ido>i have too many books in my queue to make room for a zombie apocalypse 
(11:29:23)<ido>does that make much of a difference? 
(11:29:28)<oeb>They came in two types, living vampires (Those who were alive when they got the illness) and dead ones (The already dead who rose)
(11:29:43)<oeb>Living vampires could speak and would taunt him.
(11:32:10)<oeb>In the book he was not a scientist, but an army vet who was bitten by a vampire bat many years before, hence his immunity
(11:32:35)<oeb>He went out every day and killed as many as he could, and holed up at night.
(11:33:12)<oeb>One day he finds this dog, there is a couple of chapters about his interaction with it. Very moving stuff. The dog dies.
(11:33:23)<oeb>Later he finds this woman, takes her home.
(11:33:49)<oeb>She claims to be a survivor, turns out apon a blood test that she is infected.
(11:34:45)<oeb>She reveals to him that she is part of a community of the 'living dead' people who are infected but have developed drugs to hold off the illness. They have no need to drink blood, they may go outside during the day for short periods etc.
(11:35:12)<oeb>He is a monster to them, he is the fearsome beast who kills them while they sleep.
(11:35:21)<ido>so in the book the living vampires are just normall people who need to drink blood?
(11:36:27)<oeb>There are two types, those who have succumed (They are insane etc, but can speak and show intelligence at a lower level) and the ones who are medicated who function as normall humans except for the need to sleep for at least part of the day.
(11:37:03)<oeb>When he discovers what he is and is captured by the new society, they imprision him and set him up for execution.
(11:37:07)<ido>and how do so many of them survive without the pray of normal people?
(11:37:35)<ido>do they eat one another?
(11:37:38)<oeb>The woman gives him the oppertunity to commit suicide with poision he takes them up on it.
(11:37:45)<oeb>Yes, they eat one another.
(11:38:09)<oeb>It's not explained in too much detail, but from time to time he sees them preying on one another.
(11:38:15)<oeb>Typically if one is injured.
(11:38:16)<ido>so actually their society is doomed regardless of what he does
(11:38:37)<oeb>Not really, the new society is very effeciant at killing vampires.
(11:38:57)<oeb>They do it at night when the vampires are out. He does it at day when they are asleep.
(11:38:58)<ido>newe society == the medicated vampires? 
(11:39:01)<oeb>yes
(11:39:32)<ido>but the vampires don't breed and have a limited supply of food
(11:39:39)<ido>eventually they will run out
(11:39:45)<oeb>For example when he is captured a group of 8 armed with pikes and guns easilly wipe out all the vampires outside the house.
(11:40:09)<oeb>That's not explained in too much detail, the book is set many many years after the outbreak though.
(11:40:50)<oeb>It's a short enough book, maybe 150 pages. You could read it in an afternoon easy. Well worth a read too.
(11:41:00)<ido>and can he tell the difference beteween the medicated vampires and the succmbed ones when they sleep?
(11:41:04)<oeb>No
(11:41:16)<oeb>The first he finds out about it is from the woman.
(11:42:38)<oeb>The only way he can tell if someone is infected or not is if they are out during the day. And the woman is the first one he sees outside (He does not know about the medication untill the very end).
(11:43:11)<oeb>So movie == he is a legend for curing it, book == he is a legend because he is the monster, when he thought he was the savior
(11:43:22)<ido>ok
(11:43:29)<oeb>So like I say, totally different point =P
(11:43:41)<ido>yea not really the same
(11:44:03)<oeb>It is a good book though, and like I say, nice and short, I would advise picking it up.
(11:44:35)<oeb>It's one of those 'One more chapter before I go to sleep book, Ohh shit, it's 2am already'

(10:16:39)<purestrain>i wonder if inventories in other roguelikes are more or less a 'sideeffect' or are really coded as an inventory
(10:18:22)<purestrain>perhaps i should study the source of some games
(10:21:04)<ido>what do you mean?
(10:27:10)<purestrain>i mean, do most roguelikes keep a list of inventory items for a character? for each item? or do they use a tree?
(10:27:48)<ido>what matter does it make if the underlying data structure is a tree or a linked list?
(10:28:47)<purestrain>i think a tree is easier to handle ;-)
(10:29:12)<purestrain>and its sideeffect is a inventory system
(10:29:28)<ido>i don't see how, but more importantly i  don't see why that matters
(10:29:53)<ido>and i think we are not talking about the same thing
(10:30:01)<purestrain>i was just asking what the traditionally way is
(10:31:04)<ido>tree as in http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tree_structure
(10:31:06)<ido>?
(10:31:13)<purestrain>yes
(10:31:27)<ido>what are the nodes in such a tree? for example 
(10:31:41)<purestrain>player, weapon, portion and so on
(10:32:20)<ido>i think you have formulated your question very poorly  
(10:32:55)<purestrain>perhaps i could formulate it better, if i were more used in english language ;-)
(10:33:09)<ido>by "tree" did you mean to ask if the inventory is part of the player description?
(10:33:15)<ido>it has nothing to do with english
(10:33:36)<ido>you assume we all know the structure of your design 
(10:33:40)<ido>we do not :)
(10:34:27)<purestrain>well, with tree i mean that each entity is basically a node; if they are carried or not is describes by the parent
(10:34:35)<purestrain>the root in my example would be the world
(10:34:46)<ido>ok
(10:34:53)<ido>now i understand
(10:35:31)<ido>i don't know about a "traditional" way of doing it, but:
(10:35:35)<ido>1. my games
(10:35:39)<ido>2. angband
(10:35:46)<ido>3. advanced rogue
(10:35:53)<ido>do not do it that wawy
(10:36:09)<ido>(i think, i haven't looked at all the sources of 2&3)
(10:36:34)<ido>i.e. an inventory is implemented as an inventory 
(10:36:46)<purestrain>so how do they handle relations between objects? just a linked list as inventory ?
(10:37:00)<ido>i don't know
(10:37:55)<ido>(doesn't have to be a linked list btw, that is an implementation detail) 
(10:38:16)<purestrain>of course, i mean a seperate collection/array/whatever
(10:39:53)<ido>i don't know, but i can guess that a "combined" object (like dagger + poison) is transformed to a new object (poisoned dagger) in the inventory

(05:00:06)<oeb>It's paid when you import a car.
(05:00:24)<oeb>Can you imagine having so much money you can spend three quaters of a million on a car?

(05:01:12)<ido>so that's not too bad
(05:01:21)<ido>only 4% more than normal

(05:01:42)<ido>unless you have to pay the vat in the country you bought it in as well...
(05:01:47)<ido>so that's 21% more 
(05:02:23)<oeb>For example if you bring a car that would have oridginally been worth 10,000 , but has had 20,000 worth of work done to it, you only pay the VRT off the base price. So that would be 2,500 euro
(05:02:32)<oeb>Even though you could sell it for 30,000
(05:03:11)<oeb>Alot of people import cars to Ireland. It is cheaper than buying them here mostly. The UK is much cheaper for second hand cars than Ireland.

(10:14:16)<purestrain>whats an easy way to eleminate artifacts? i would say: if a tile is visible, the surrounding walls are visible too
(10:14:57)<joe6pack>i never needed to eliminate anything. plain ol' check if every cell is in the los works perfectly for me 
(10:14:59)<RotateMe>if a tile is visible make all tiles in the opposite direction of the player visible
(10:15:32)<joe6pack>if a tile is visible make all the tiles on the map visible 
(10:15:51)<RotateMe>so if a lit tile is above and left of the player make the tile left of it, the tile above it and the tile left-above it visible
(10:16:19)<RotateMe>replace left-above with the correct english term and you're done :D

(11:14:27)<the_ru>the first time you kill a creature of each type, you get a point in that skill
(11:14:40)<the_ru>after enough points, the skill improves
(11:14:58)<the_ru>so you'd have to "dedicate" your kills to a weapon type

(11:31:07)<the_ru>a real dragon wouldn't let you get that close :-)
(11:31:11)<jomiolto>but I think that is a good point

(11:34:04)<jomiolto>and because of that you need to up the hp count, unless you want to have instakills lurking around every corner

(11:32:33)<the_ru>in C, can I malloc a 2-dimensional array directly?
(11:33:40)<the_ru>i.e. a ** pointer
(11:34:42)<jomiolto>a ** pointer is not a 2-dim array, but an array of pointers, I think
(11:34:47)<the_ru>hm, yes
(11:34:50)<the_ru>you are correct
(11:34:56)<Aerton>malloc just gives you a chunk of memory, you can cast it to whatever you want
(11:35:18)<the_ru>the first pointer points to an array of pointers, which in turn point to arrays of actual values
(11:35:25)<Aerton>yes
(11:35:49)<the_ru>but how do I access a specific y,x pair then?
(11:35:53)<the_ru>if it's just a chunk
(11:36:34)<Aerton>first, you alloc an array for pointers
(11:37:14)<Aerton>then you make these pointers refer to correct positions in allocated chunk (or use an individual malloc for each one)
(11:37:55)<the_ru>that
(11:38:01)<the_ru>'s what I'm doing now - individual malloc
(11:38:05)<jomiolto>or you can just malloc a single block to a normal pointer and do: pointer[x + y * x_length]
(11:38:21)<jomiolto>but I guess some people don't like that kind of a thing...
(11:38:28)<the_ru>the problem isn't the allocation, but the freeing - I have multiple return points
(11:38:48)<the_ru>I guess I could exchange them for a flag that I check at the end instead
(11:39:07)<Aerton>you'd want dedicated functions to alloc/init and free such things
(11:39:24)<jomiolto>yes, generally you should abstract that kind of things behind functions
(11:40:07)<TMC>cast to array!
(11:40:58)<the_ru>it's a one time thing, this *is* the function for abstraction :-O
(11:42:48)<the_ru>ahaha!

(12:37:12)<Glowie>I see

(12:39:07)<TMC>and that it's always ingnored
(12:39:19)<TMC>it seems like it should be an important problem!
(12:40:09)<TMC>hmm, that fov does seem a bit odd
(12:40:31)<TMC>because of the shadows cast by single tile walls
(12:40:52)<jomiolto>yeah, I know, that does seem a bit odd
(12:41:09)<TMC>are you checking visibility of the center point of a tile?
(12:41:12)<jomiolto>but I think it's quite close to a permissive fov
(12:41:46)<jomiolto>no, not really, it's a modification of a simple raycasting algo
(12:42:14)<Glowie>Players won't notice unless the fov is really off :P
(12:42:14)<purestrain>looks quite ok for a tilebased game
(12:43:20)<jomiolto>at least it looks a lot better than my older one that was simple raycasting with bresenham's algorithms :P
(12:45:14)<jomiolto>is there a list of different fov algos somewhere? I'd like to see if this particular idea has been implemented in roguelikes before, or if I actually came up with something new
(12:46:29)<jomiolto>oh, never mind, already found a list at roguebasin
(12:46:39)<TMC>so, what is it?
(12:46:50)<TMC>a tile is lit if a ray is cast through any part of it?
(12:47:45)<TMC>no, that can't be it
(12:48:25)<jomiolto>the idea is to start with only 8 rays and then increase the number of rays as you get farther away from the center of the fov
(12:51:02)<jomiolto>I guess I could write an article about this on roguebasin, or something
(12:51:11)<jomiolto>it might be of interest to someone
(12:51:50)<jomiolto>the algorithm is actually very simple and doesn't require a "real" implementation of neither line nor circle algorithm
(12:53:38)<TMC>what do you mean by that?
(12:54:43)<jomiolto>it does the raytracing recursively, so it doesn't need anything like bresenham's line algorithm
(12:54:50)<Glowie>Is it fast too?
(12:54:56)<jomiolto>I'm not really sure
(12:55:22)<jomiolto>I think it's somewhere in between O(n^2) and O(n^3), but not exactly sure
(12:56:02)<jomiolto>I really need to test it on a bigger map...
(12:57:23)<TMC>you are planning on using bigger maps?
(12:58:02)<jomiolto>not really, but I just want to test how fast it is in practise
(12:58:50)<jomiolto>that 50x50 level on the screenshot takes less than a millisecond to render, so it isn't really a good measure of how quick it is :)
(01:01:57)<TMC>well technically, you should just run it repeatedly (over different maps) rather than over one massive map
(01:02:09)<TMC>though I suppose there's probably no difference
(01:03:08)<jomiolto>oh, I think there's a pretty big difference actually, since this algorithm only goes through actually visible tiles
(01:03:18)<jomiolto>having a lot of walls should make it a lot faster
(01:16:07)<jomiolto>weird, the performance really sucks with a radius bigger than 25 :/
(01:16:21)<jomiolto>r=25 renders in under a millisecond, while r=50 takes 0.4seconds
(01:16:52)<jomiolto>I think there's a bug in the code...
(01:17:15)<TMC>hmmm
(01:20:01)<Roor>Hi
(01:21:59)<Aerton>angband uses something remotely similar
(01:22:15)<jomiolto>ah, no, it's the algorithm. All the recursion makes its execution time grow exponentially :/
(01:22:36)<jomiolto>I think it can be solved, though
(01:22:52)<Aerton>it has a precalculated table that indicated what new rays should be started from every cell

(10:02:15)<the_ru>...
(10:02:19)<the_ru>I think I caught it
(10:02:38)<the_ru>there seem to be cases where turn_func can kill the creature
(10:02:48)<the_ru>for example, if it steps on a lethal trap
(10:03:15)<the_ru>I currently don't have any way to pass back to the caller that such a thing happened
(10:03:54)<the_ru>so I have to check the levels creature[] array and see if the creature is still in there - i.e. it's still alive
(10:04:00)<the_ru>and the pointer is valid
(10:04:01)<the_ru>:-(
(10:04:56)<the_ru>... and about now you're probably all wondering what the hell I'm talking about
(10:04:58)<the_ru>I'm not sure myself
(10:06:13)<the_ru>perhaps I should just add a "dead" flag in the creature_t struct, that I flip
(10:06:26)<the_ru>and then let the main game loop free the memory
(10:07:00)<the_ru>but that would require if (creature->dead) checks in many places
(10:07:02)<the_ru>I imagine
(10:07:04)<the_ru>How do you do it?
(10:08:03)<the_ru>... and I'm not really expecting any interpreted/GC-equipped language geeks to answer that
(10:08:20)<jomiolto>hmm, I had a similar problem, but I don't remember how I solved it
(10:10:04)<jomiolto>I think I somehow made it so that monsters are only killed in one place in the code, and that code removed all the references to the monster from everywhere
(10:10:26)<the_ru>yeah, I think that makes sense
(10:10:44)<the_ru>I'm sure I had some reason NOT to do it that way, but I can't remember what it was :-/
(10:11:24)<jomiolto>it actually gets really ugly when you have a lot of references to the monsters/other things all around the place
(10:12:48)<jomiolto>for example I had items that could have a monster as their owner, and then AI code also needed references whenever a monster attacked another monster, etc.
(10:13:12)<the_ru>yeah
(10:13:18)<the_ru>I have master->minion relationships
(10:13:57)<the_ru>I keep them in a global 2D array, where each row is a relationship, index 0 is the master and index 1 is the minion
(10:14:12)<the_ru>since the master and minion might end up on different levels
(10:14:40)<the_ru>and I don't want to search EVERY creature on EVERY level for a reference if I remove either of them
(10:15:01)<the_ru>it's better to have them in a list, and have get_master() etc functions
(10:15:46)<the_ru>but anyway, in many places I'm using the return value of functions to tell the caller if the creature pointer is still valid
(10:16:21)<the_ru>but it feels like there are better uses for the return values
(10:16:57)<the_ru>and in some places I simply need them for other things, that's why I had to do it this way with the traps
(10:17:10)<jomiolto>I've considered putting all the monsters/items/etc. in lists from which they can be referenced with an integer index, instead of a pointer
(10:17:25)<the_ru>yeah, been thinking of that too
(10:17:37)<the_ru>it ought to make saving/loading easier as well
(10:17:44)<the_ru>although I'm not adding that to my game
(10:17:45)<jomiolto>that way there will not be problems with pointers, but there is a performance penalty, unless there is some smart ninja way to do it
(10:18:14)<the_ru>what language are you using?
(10:18:17)<jomiolto>C
(10:18:29)<the_ru>I wouldn't worry about the performance then
(10:18:39)<jomiolto>I can't really help it :)
(10:18:43)<jomiolto>I'm so used to it
(10:18:57)<the_ru>I can guarantee there are better places to hunt cycles :-)
(10:19:35)<jomiolto>I used to do a lot of coding when I only had a 66MHz 486 machine, and that really required some optimizing even for some relatively simple things
(10:19:38)<the_ru>BTW, an example: my activate_trap() function only takes a trap_t pointer as argument, and figures out on its own which creature is standing on it
(10:20:19)<the_ru>a trap could also kill multiple creatures, so either way it would be very inconvenient to try to track them
(10:20:31)<jomiolto>yeah
(10:21:34)<the_ru>My creatures take almost 54k memory :-O
(10:21:38)<the_ru>... each
(10:21:45)<jomiolto>what? how did you manage that? :D
(10:23:31)<the_ru>well, 13k are just for LOS tables and such things
(10:23:51)<jomiolto>oh, you do LOS for all the monsters?
(10:24:05)<the_ru>yes
(10:24:21)<the_ru>and I regenerate everything every turn, and keep it in a table :-/
(10:24:32)<the_ru>instead of just calculating the lines I need when I need them
(10:25:16)<jomiolto>I simply check if there is something interesting in the radius of the monster's vision, and then check if there is a line-of-sight from those interesting things to the monster
(10:26:09)<the_ru>unlike 99% of the RL developers out there, I don't think it's very interesting to create the ultimate LOS
(10:26:25)<jomiolto>"ultimate LOS"?
(10:26:31)<jomiolto>something like a really cool los algo?
(10:26:36)<the_ru>I just use a brute force approach, calculate everything with 360 degree precision just in case, and proceed to write actual game content
(10:26:42)<the_ru>yes
(10:26:58)<jomiolto>do you use raycasting or something else?
(10:27:14)<the_ru>it seems like there's always a thread in the newsgroups about the most efficient LOS implementation
(10:27:18)<the_ru>I have no idea
(10:27:31)<jomiolto>heh, I'm actually developing a new LOS algorithm :)
(10:27:33)<the_ru>I "cast" "rays" in a way, but I dunno if it's actually raycasting
(10:27:57)<jomiolto>I currently use raycasting, but it's an O(n^3) implementation of it, because I want it to look nice
(10:28:10)<jomiolto>and it gets too slow at longer radii
(10:28:14)<the_ru>starting at each creature, I use sin and cos to shoot rays into all directions
(10:28:44)<the_ru>it's "fast enough" that no one has ever complained, and I honestly don't notice it being slow
(10:29:23)<jomiolto>of course, if you only use small radii with LOS, it is not going to matter that much, but I want it to be usable at something like radius=25 or longer
(10:29:49)<the_ru>I use 40, don't notice any slowness
(10:29:52)<jomiolto>:/
(10:30:02)<jomiolto>then your LOS must be much more efficient than my current one
(10:30:09)<the_ru>I don't have the patience to keep reinventing the wheel, it feels like I'm falling behind in the race :-/
(10:30:18)<jomiolto>yeah, that is true
(10:30:27)<jomiolto>sometimes it really sucks to be a perfectionist :(
(10:30:30)<the_ru>the race against time, since I know some day I won't be able or won't want to work on this anymore
(10:30:39)<the_ru>I want to finish
(10:31:01)<the_ru>I don't think it's very efficient, I just don't care
(10:31:05)<jomiolto>and I don't even think that it matters so much in the end, because most of the players are not going to notice anything ,unless the LOS is really *ugly*
(10:31:53)<the_ru>if it's a fun game, I think people will accept it
(10:32:02)<the_ru>... or fix it for you, if it's open source ;-)
(10:32:23)<jomiolto>but I think now I'm going to stick with this LOS that I'm developing, since it looks as good as the old one (or even better) and is a lot faster
(10:32:44)<the_ru>do you have level validation?
(10:32:51)<jomiolto>what's that?
(10:33:20)<the_ru>I check mine for stuff like connectivity (all tiles must be reachable), that stairs are built where they are supposed to, etc
(10:33:32)<the_ru>the connectivity is probably the most inefficient routine I have, but it works
(10:33:45)<jomiolto>well, yeah, it is kind of built into the dungeon generation. All the dungeons generated will be sane
(10:34:00)<the_ru>I count the number of traversable tiles, then floodfill them and see if the numbers match
(10:34:14)<jomiolto>when it comes to LOS, I would like to implement something like this: http://roguebasin.roguelikedevelopment.org/index.php?title=Digital_field_of_view_implementation
(10:34:16)<the_ru>if there are more traversable tiles than floodfilled ones, there ought to be a cut-off section somewhere
(10:34:23)<jomiolto>but it's way too complex for me to understand :/
(10:34:53)<jomiolto>I actually use quite a many different dungeon generators for my main roguelike
(10:35:33)<jomiolto>there are wilderness levels, caves, mines, troll caves, etc.
(10:35:36)<the_ru>I have two so far
(10:35:40)<the_ru>and variants of those
(10:35:58)<jomiolto>the wilderness one was actually really fun to code and I really like it :)
(10:36:03)<the_ru>one generates 90% valid maps, but I want a bit of randomness
(10:36:19)<jomiolto>it generates forests, swamps, hills, mountains and river/lake levels
(10:36:19)<the_ru>could be 100%, but then they'd be too predictable
(10:36:24)<the_ru>a-ha

(10:37:09)<jomiolto>well, I have an overworld like in ADOM and you can "enter" wilderness squares, which basically just generates a random level according to your surroudings

(01:30:13)<cellyboy>I have a linked list containing all entities, and arrays for the World/Dungeon/Map/Tile's
(01:30:28)<cellyboy>yeah, i suppose that would work
(01:30:52)<cellyboy>Sending too many pointers here and there would be spaghetti as far as I can see it...
(01:31:09)<cellyboy>and would probably get me problems later on...
(01:31:14)<Kadwiell>Well, this is a code design issue, so the answer is probably "whatever you're most comfortable with"
(01:31:18)<cellyboy>yeah
(01:31:20)<cellyboy>i suppose
(01:31:57)<cellyboy>This is my third try for creating a roguelike, the last two tries I started in the wrong end and ended up in some kind've limbo where I couldnt do anything since it was like positioning a straight block through a round hole...
(01:32:13)<cellyboy>so this time i started off at the heart of the game as I see it, the EventHandler...
(01:32:41)<cellyboy>which handles whoms turn it is, and also handles all the effects and when they should take place...
(01:33:08)<cellyboy>learning by doing I guess it's called ;p
(01:33:17)<Kadwiell>That's where I started with my 7DRL.. but I changed my mind about how it should work during the seven days :)
(01:33:58)<cellyboy>yeah, but building the eventhandler around the events would be.. odd how I see it.. I guess one needs to adjust it, but the general idea is thought up already :)
(01:35:12)<Kadwiell>Yeah, event handler first is probably best.. just expect that you'll change your mind about things later
(01:35:29)<Kadwiell>I take it you're working on non-nDRL projects?
(01:35:34)<cellyboy>yeah, i suppose, but then most of the changes will happen in the Entity class and it's children...
(01:35:37)<cellyboy>yes
(01:35:50)<cellyboy>it's a long term project, or atleast I hope it will be :)
(01:35:59)<cellyboy>with 7drl
(01:36:10)<cellyboy>one can accept a portion of ugly code
(01:36:19)<cellyboy>since the project in general is fairly limited.
(01:36:32)<Kadwiell>Yeah
(01:36:57)<Kadwiell>I agree that a non-nDRL should be prettier, but code in general increases in entropy, is my experience
(01:37:12)<cellyboy>aye
(01:37:41)<cellyboy>i'm pretty happy about the eventhandler though, it's only limited in the way I chose to have my Entity class and it's children
(01:38:21)<cellyboy>Everything is an Entity, spells, effects, monsters, players, whatever I may see fit...
(01:38:44)<Kadwiell>And the common feature of entities is that they act in some manner controlled by the event handler?
(01:39:21)<cellyboy>basically each time an entity is looped through the eventhandler checks if it's that events turn to act, if it is, it calls a function onDefault(void)
(01:39:42)<cellyboy>which in turn calls upon either AI, player controls, whatever i chose...
(01:40:20)<cellyboy>I may add additional things later on, but for now this does the trick by far.
(01:40:22)<cellyboy>:)
(01:40:29)<Kadwiell>Sounds reasonable :)
(01:40:45)<cellyboy>The general idea I got from an article on roguebasin...
(01:41:00)<cellyboy>it's called "Elegant Roguelike...something..."
(01:41:09)<cellyboy>Elegant handler, or Elegant timekeeping or something..hmm
(01:42:04)<cellyboy>also allows for very very very distinct speeds for each unit.. the resolution for speed settings is huge
(01:42:31)<Kadwiell>Do you use something queuelike for the eventhandler?
(01:43:11)<cellyboy>a linked list containing all entities, which each contain a value "int currrentActionPoints" and "int initialActionPoints"
(01:43:21)<Kadwiell>Hm, also: something to keep in mind with huge speed setting resolutions
(01:43:24)<cellyboy>a unit with speed 20 is 5 times as fast as one with 100...
(01:43:40)<Kadwiell>That is generally my speed system as well :)
(01:44:06)<Kadwiell>But: the player may want to see all movement, getting --more-- prompts and such when there's an excess of movement before she gets to act
(01:44:20)<cellyboy>yeah, that's true...
(01:44:26)<Kadwiell>Is that possible? (I ask because I ignored this in my 7drl..)
(01:44:26)<cellyboy>atleast if something important happens
(01:44:29)<cellyboy>like getting attacked....
(01:44:41)<cellyboy>or getting cast a spell at...
(01:44:48)<cellyboy>general movement i wouldnt deem that neccesary...
(01:44:53)<Kadwiell>Or if it's a relatively long time until they get to act, such as if they're paralyzed or just fighting a very fast monster
(01:45:00)<cellyboy>aye
(01:45:07)<cellyboy>that's very possible...
(01:45:28)<cellyboy>Lets say a speed-20 monster hits a speed 100 player..
(01:45:55)<cellyboy>a --more-- prompt would be great, so the player doesnt suffer like 5 hits and has no idea what happened..
(01:46:09)<cellyboy>but that can be built in quite easily i suppose
(01:47:00)<cellyboy>one thing would be to just add it in the attack code...
(01:47:06)<Kadwiell>Yep, but it's an UI event outside the player's act()
(01:47:15)<Kadwiell>Which is easy to forget to plan for
(01:47:20)<cellyboy>hmmm
(01:47:37)<cellyboy>what do you mean?
(01:47:48)<cellyboy>I have my player as a separate child class under Entity...
(01:48:09)<cellyboy>with it's own onDefault() containing controls...
(01:48:21)<cellyboy>not sure if this is the right way to go, but it has worked fine so far :)
(01:48:30)<cellyboy>I'm not so far gone with the RL though :)
(01:49:20)<Kadwiell>I mean if you have all other UI stuff under Player->onDefault(), this might lead to some confusion later on
(01:49:50)<Kadwiell>But I think the general wisdom is to get the @ moving onscreen as soon as possible, and _then_ worry about the perfect design :)
(01:50:01)<cellyboy>welll
(01:50:13)<cellyboy>i tried that twice, and got stuck :p call me a newbie, but bah

(01:51:59)<cellyboy>i.e UI::message("Hiya!");
(01:52:07)<cellyboy>or UI::more();
(01:52:40)<Kadwiell>Okay, then it sounds like you will avoid that particular trap
(01:53:19)<Kadwiell>Just call UI::more() when the notification console fills up, something moves twice without an update, or something similar

(01:40:41)<the_ru>I don't generate them specifically, but they are often created anyway
(01:40:55)<the_ru>that is the algorithm I described, with a few tweaks
(01:41:19)<the_ru>it can also generate rooms within rooms, but that isn't shown there
(01:41:34)<the_ru>i.e. a block of rooms that is completely contained within another room
(01:41:54)<the_ru>it also builds moats randomly, with the same method
(01:41:58)<TMC>do you use several different map generators for tsl?
(01:42:06)<the_ru>yes
(01:42:23)<the_ru>really just two right now
(01:42:33)<the_ru>and then two or three more derived from one of those
(01:43:34)<TMC>hmmm
(01:43:51)<TMC>this map doesn't look much like it was crated by repeatively splitting!
(01:44:14)<the_ru>it was
(01:44:19)<TMC>you just carve a rectangular chunk out of the room?
(01:44:29)<the_ru>but then I run another algorithm over it that removes random walls
(01:45:17)<the_ru>the 1st recursion takes the whole map as arguments
(01:45:22)<TMC>oh, so you actually just split each room (which starts rectangular) with a single straight line?
(01:45:29)<the_ru>yes
(01:46:23)<the_ru>you can even write it so that it *always* generates connected maps
(01:46:33)<TMC>neat, removing walls seems pretty powerful then
(01:47:12)<the_ru>as you can see, I fill random areas with walls completely - removing a few % from the valid map ration
(01:47:28)<the_ru>but I already have tests for it anyway, and I like the extra randomness
(01:48:03)<the_ru>just keep splitting them until the rooms get as small as you want them
(01:48:21)<the_ru>and with a few special cases you can have all the hallways you want
(01:49:42)<TMC>yes
(01:49:52)<TMC>thanks, that was very helpful
(01:50:34)<TMC>removing walls would be an easy way to keep rooms above a minimum size, with interesting shpes and easy placement

(05:26:01)<the_ru>Yes
(05:26:14)<the_ru>I'm pondering if Dodge should be a skill with Speed as base attribute

(05:26:53)<the_ru>I used to have Evasion which was a combination of dodge and stealth
(05:27:58)<the_ru>I don't think it matters much
(05:28:16)<the_ru>I don't really need to have a symmetric skill tree or anything
(05:30:14)<the_ru>and I wonder how visible my skills should be
(05:30:26)<the_ru>should they all be on a list, or should they just appear as they are learned?
(05:30:43)<the_ru>the second approach would offer more replayability, I think
(05:31:15)<the_ru>even if you "know" the game, you can pursue some obscure combination of skills that have some kind of synergic effect
(05:32:19)<Kadwiell>To the spoiled player it probably won't matter whether they are listed or not
(05:32:44)<Kadwiell>But whether getting the first skill point / "learning the skill" is a huge issue does matter, of course
(05:32:58)<Kadwiell>Do you plan to restrict the number of skills a player can learn?
(05:33:03)<the_ru>well, it could make it easier for new players
(05:33:19)<the_ru>if they only need to be concerned about the skills they know - no need to wonder "What does that do?"
(05:33:27)<the_ru>well, not really
(05:33:31)<the_ru>they skills are active all the time
(05:33:45)<the_ru>they're just modifiers to the success rolls of your actions
(05:35:17)<the_ru>and should attributes care about skills?
(05:35:35)<Kadwiell>Hm, then it could be good to have them all listed as well, so new player can know what areas they may improve at later
(05:35:36)<the_ru>like, if you have an extremely high dodge skill, it ought to "wear off" on your general Speed attribute
(05:36:05)<Kadwiell>So they can think "I'm apparently useless at stealth at the moment" rather than "stealth seems to be useless in this game"
(05:36:38)<the_ru>hm
(05:36:47)<the_ru>well, OTOH, some characters shouldn't know about some skills
(05:37:06)<the_ru>like a fighter that doesn't care about magic shouldn't even be aware what different magic schools there are
(05:37:39)<Kadwiell>Well, if your game is strict-classed and there are some skills that are just plain useless for some classes, you could just hide them
(05:38:00)<Kadwiell>But someone who's not a rogue might want to learn stealth, for instance..
(05:38:35)<the_ru>yes, but that is done in other ways
(05:39:10)<the_ru>character advancement will probably be through choices you make at "checkpoints"
(05:39:43)<the_ru>the checkpoints will be statues at the end of the various areas, that house ancient spirits that share their knowledge
(05:40:07)<the_ru>so you never browse a skill list and think "hm, what could be useful here"
(05:40:15)<Kadwiell>Hm, right
(05:42:09)<the_ru>it's more take what you can get and make the best of it
(05:42:12)<Kadwiell>Not a bad idea, equating character and spatial progress
(05:42:27)<Kadwiell>But still, I think roguelike players will always want to plan ahead to some degree
(05:43:06)<Kadwiell>If you find the Cloak of Awesome Stealth, you'll want to hang onto it only if you think that your character will ever have a chance in the stealth parts of the game
(05:43:25)<Kadwiell>So it's a useful thing to know even when you're not "leveling up"
(05:43:29)<the_ru>I don't have any experience, levels or classes :-)

(05:52:12)<the_ru>you get a stealth bonus for moving in shadow
(05:52:20)<the_ru>and from stealth skill, of course
(05:52:33)<the_ru>it's rolled against the perception of each creature within sight
(05:52:45)<the_ru>or rather, each creature that can see *you*

(05:54:33)<the_ru>indeed

(05:58:05)<the_ru>it's quite easy actually

(05:58:20)<the_ru>you leave a certain amount of your scent on each tile
(05:58:27)<the_ru>then it decays over time
(05:58:36)<the_ru>the monsters just move in the direction it's strongest

(09:30:19)<the_ru>huh
(09:30:23)<the_ru>what are you talking about now?
(09:30:39)<jomiolto>I'm talking about my roguelike library that should work for 2-3 different roguelikes
(09:31:14)<jomiolto>I guess I'm setting too high standards
(09:31:30)<the_ru>example?
(09:32:20)<jomiolto>I want to, for example, support both tile graphics and ASCII without having to write both of them from the ground up
(09:32:38)<jomiolto>but it's just that tile graphics are in so many ways different from ASCII
(09:32:53)<the_ru>they shouldn't be, to the caller
(09:33:19)<the_ru>it should just be a matter of display_tile(y, x, tile) either way
(09:33:24)<jomiolto>yeah, that's the thing, I want the same code to work for both, but there are some differences between them that make it very difficult
(09:33:38)<the_ru>such as?
(09:34:28)<the_ru>I guess sometimes you have to settle for the least common denominator
(09:34:33)<jomiolto>like the fact that ASCII only shows one "tile" at a time in a single place, while in tile graphics you might see a glimpse of an item under a monster and then a glimpse of the level tile under it
(09:34:50)<the_ru>then store it in layers
(09:35:12)<the_ru>tile, item, creature, effects (spells, etc)
(09:35:32)<the_ru>I currently have tile, trap, item, creature
(09:35:44)<jomiolto>that's what I'm basically doing now, but it complicates the code :/
(09:36:40)<the_ru>I don't see why it should
(09:36:50)<the_ru>unless you use some very sophisticated level memory or something
(09:37:10)<the_ru>I just remember the wall/floor layout, no items or such things like Nethack does
(09:37:48)<jomiolto>my code also remembers items, but that's not really the problem
(09:38:24)<jomiolto>with simple one tile at a single location all you need to do is to get the tile at x, y and paint it, if it's visible, but when you can have a stack of tiles, you need to paint them in order
(09:38:43)<the_ru>ok?
(09:38:44)<jomiolto>and the problem is that those tiles come from different places
(09:38:57)<jomiolto>monsters are in a different place, items in another diffrent place, and so on
(09:39:03)<the_ru>yes
(09:39:17)<the_ru>but what is the problem? just loop across those structures then?
(09:39:21)<jomiolto>I've been thinking about storing them all in a single list, and using some kind of polymorphism, but that once again makes it more complicated :)
(09:39:54)<jomiolto>well, there's no real problem, but I'd just like to keep the code as simple as possible
(09:39:57)<the_ru>I have the map as a 2D array, which overlaps with the level memory, then traps and items in a linked list, and creatures in an array
(09:41:07)<jomiolto>anyway, that is nothing compared to having support for animations and such, and still trying to make it work with same code as the ASCII
(09:41:29)<the_ru>is it threaded?
(09:41:32)<jomiolto>nope
(09:41:36)<the_ru>a-ha
(09:41:42)<jomiolto>but I think I have a nice solution for it
(09:41:43)<the_ru>well, animations could be a problem then
(09:42:45)<jomiolto>I'm just going to abstract the event loop away from the game to the library, so the different parts of the library can implement the event loop in different ways and handle animation and such
(09:43:08)<the_ru>the event loop?
(09:43:16)<the_ru>the same place the game logic takes place in?
(09:43:19)<jomiolto>uhm, yeah I think that's what it's called
(09:43:35)<jomiolto>nope, it just reads the input from user and calls the correct "event handlers"
(09:43:51)<jomiolto>then the game logic will take place in those event handlers
(09:44:00)<the_ru>when do monsters get to move?
(09:44:24)<jomiolto>they move after an event
(09:44:35)<jomiolto>it's turn based, so that won't be a problem
(09:45:01)<the_ru>what if you want to pause the game between different actions?
(09:45:11)<the_ru>like a monster firing an arrow - the player should have a chance to see it
(09:45:31)<the_ru>how does that work with the animation loop?
(09:46:03)<jomiolto>that is another problem, because such things would look quite different on ASCII and graphics
(09:46:50)<jomiolto>but it could be either implemented by the event loop (disable event handling until the arrow has hit something) or by the game logic code
(09:47:46)<the_ru>heh
(09:47:50)<the_ru>well, roguelikes are hard
(09:48:03)<jomiolto>but that is one of the things where I'm probably going to have to write different code for ASCII and graphics
(09:48:03)<the_ru>since the data and presentation are so tightly connected
(09:48:22)<jomiolto>yeah, I've noticed that during the years I've tried to develop a roguelike :)
(09:48:40)<the_ru>I think you should try to keep the game logic in the game code
(09:48:46)<jomiolto>yes, I know
(09:49:21)<the_ru>either that, or create a separate thread that deals with animation and stuff. then you could only set a few flags to update what's going on on-screen
(09:49:39)<the_ru>but you'd still need to manually flush updates if it's running in text mode
(09:50:21)<jomiolto>well, I could use threads for graphics, but I don't think I'm going that way for ASCII -- I wan't to keep the ASCII stuff as simple as possible
(09:50:51)<the_ru>probably a good idea
(09:51:05)<the_ru>and thanks for reminding me why I'm not making a graphical version :-)
(09:51:11)<jomiolto>heh :)
(09:51:40)<the_ru>I'm pondering making one just to see how well logic and UI separates...
(09:51:41)<jomiolto>I wasn't originally going to do that either, but after I found a nice tile set and saw how different the game looked and felt with graphics, I just had to go for it
(09:51:50)<the_ru>but I have other things I'd like to work on for now
(09:51:59)<the_ru>which one?
(09:52:02)<the_ru>Lost Dragons?
(09:52:11)<jomiolto>hmm, I'm sure where I found it
(09:52:41)<jomiolto>there were tiles for Crawl and Nethack I think, 32x32
(09:52:58)<the_ru>A-ha
(09:53:11)<the_ru>http://www.lostdragon.com/tiles/db-bmp-tiles.zip
(09:53:17)<the_ru>Those are great anyway

(09:53:51)<jomiolto>that's the one, I think
(09:55:28)<jomiolto>http://www.hytti.uku.fi/~jmtoivan/exador/exador000.png <- there's a crappy screenshot of them, but they look much better when there are more things around (items, monsters, etc.)
(09:57:20)<jomiolto>oh, and then there's this: http://rltiles.sourceforge.net/dc-pl.html
(09:57:44)<jomiolto>I somehow found it very interesting to write code that displays the items your PC is wearing :)
(09:57:55)<the_ru>yeah
(09:58:08)<the_ru>paperdolls are great - I wonder why so few use them
(09:58:33)<the_ru>and when they do, they are very poorly implemented (Morrowind comes to mind)

(10:02:49)<jomiolto>I don't have one bit of a graphical artist in me, so I can't really get anything done graphics-wise :/
(10:03:26)<jomiolto>although, at one point I was going to make a platformer with stickman graphics, but even that turned out to be quite difficult :)

(07:06:15)<the_ru>making missile weapons equipping both hands is a bit too much, but at least one hand
(07:06:39)<the_ru>that's realistic as well - you can still pull the bowstring even if you have a dagger in your other hand
(07:07:14)<RotateMe>well you most often have some thing on your girdle to put your sword/dagger/etc. away fast to use your hands
(07:07:36)<the_ru>as you said, it doesn't contribute to fun
(07:07:42)<RotateMe>yep
(07:08:19)<the_ru>but somehow I want to prevent people from dual-wielding two battleaxes, having a bow ready in some imaginary third hand AND being able to cast spells at any time
(07:08:31)<RotateMe>if the player wants that kind of deepness, he can imagine that the player puts his stuff away himself while using the spell
(07:09:09)<RotateMe>what advantages do you give when the player dualwields?
(07:09:23)<the_ru>well, two attacks in one turn
(07:09:41)<the_ru>they still take as much time as two individual attacks, but you get to perform them right after each other
(07:09:50)<RotateMe>i did it like that as well but you get a lot of disadvantages
(07:10:00)<RotateMe>for the second attack that is
(07:10:04)<RotateMe>AND you have no shield
(07:10:08)<the_ru>so the two attacks could kill the enemy right away, instead of hitting, getting hit, then hitting again
(07:10:36)<RotateMe>ah but it takes longer?
(07:10:42)<the_ru>yes
(07:10:45)<RotateMe>okay
(07:10:53)<the_ru>it takes twice the time before you can do anything again
(07:10:58)<the_ru>or something like that
(07:11:04)<the_ru>I'm not 100% sure how the math works actually
(07:11:19)<RotateMe>:D
(07:11:42)<the_ru>Also; it does matter what hand each weapon is in
(07:11:53)<the_ru>but there is no way for the player to configure that
(07:11:57)<RotateMe>doesn't he need some sort of skill?
(07:12:15)<RotateMe>in dungeonhunter it's not possible to dualwield without the passive skill
(07:12:22)<the_ru>the weapon that has been in the inventory the shortest time is considered the first
(07:12:26)<the_ru>yes, it needs a skill
(07:12:40)<the_ru>and it gives a -2 to-hit penalty as well
(07:16:32)<RotateMe>okay i think that's fine then
(07:16:39)<RotateMe>don't give any more disadvantages
(07:19:24)<the_ru>well, how about I keep track of the hands?
(07:20:01)<the_ru>when using a one-handed weapon, with or without a shield), there are no modifiers
(07:20:11)<the_ru>two-handed weapons get +1 to-hit
(07:20:24)<the_ru>dual-wielding gives a -2 to the weapon in the non-dominant hand
(07:20:55)<the_ru>it wouldn't keep track of the actual handedness of the character, just where each weapon was
(07:21:50)<the_ru>when using a ranged weapon, it would occupy the non-dominant hand
(07:22:42)<the_ru>or I could let the player hot-key "weapon sets", and spend a turn swapping

(07:28:02)<the_ru>        additional function on a device or in a system not
(07:28:02)<the_ru>        essential to the basic operation. -- Commonly used in the
(07:28:02)<the_ru>        phrase no frills, used adjectively to indicate a fully
(07:28:02)<the_ru>        functional but economical device or service; as, an
(07:28:05)<the_ru>        economical no-frills airline.

Thus, for example, one can expect one of the commands ‚Äòx‚Äô, ‚Äòq‚Äô, or ‚ÄòC-x C-c‚Äô to terminate a program written to this pattern.

(08:38:04)<Kadwiell>You have to plan your movements and stay in the shadows or out of sight
(08:38:37)<the_ru>But should it be a toggle?
(08:38:57)<the_ru>obviously, attacking someone would break it
(08:39:19)<the_ru>but OTOH, attacking someone when hidden would result in a backstab, if you had that skill

(08:46:57)<the_ru>I really need to get this into testing ASAP
(08:47:04)<TMC>testing/
(08:47:07)<TMC>?
(08:47:16)<the_ru>uh
(08:47:28)<the_ru>continuing a discussion from 10 hours ago :-)
(08:47:38)<the_ru>I'm working on a new stealth system
(08:48:10)<TMC>I think it heard mentioned
(08:48:31)<TMC>with stealth as a skill instead of an intrinsic?
(08:49:22)<the_ru>no, that would just be a cosmetic change
(08:49:31)<the_ru>I'm changing the way stealth works
(08:49:39)<the_ru>you have a number of stealth points
(08:49:49)<the_ru>when you're on a dark tile, you regain them
(08:50:03)<the_ru>when you're on a lit tile, they are reduced
(08:50:08)<TMC>trippy
(08:50:18)<the_ru>once depleted, enemies can see you
(08:50:47)<the_ru>some actions also cost stealth
(08:51:06)<the_ru>closing doors, for example, will cost stealth *and* attract enemies to the source of the sound
(08:53:08)<the_ru>attacking will always reveal you, but you get a 3x damage bonus on the first strike
(08:58:53)<the_ru>Right now I have a bar displaying how much stealth you have left
(08:59:00)<the_ru>so you can time your movements
(08:59:49)<the_ru>it seems like a sane compromise; even if you can plan exactly how to sneak there's always the chance of an enemy moving or you stepping on a trap
(09:07:27)<TMC>that sounds like a really cool syst3m
(09:08:13)<the_ru>in theory, yes
(09:08:35)<the_ru>I just hope I can implement it in a way that is challenging yet feel natural
(09:09:06)<the_ru>so far, it feels like stealth is much more useful
(09:09:31)<the_ru>it used to be just a roll you made each turn, to see if the enemies saw you
(09:09:34)<the_ru>know it allows planning
(09:09:51)<the_ru>know/now
(09:10:29)<the_ru>the weight of your equipment makes a much bigger difference also
(09:10:54)<the_ru>I just had two good suits of armor to choose from - picked the lighter one since it wouldn't ruin my stealth
(09:11:27)<the_ru>and trap detection is much more useful as well, since they aren't just HP reduction anymore - they make noise
(09:12:16)<the_ru>I'm not 100% sure how to handle ranged weapons though
(09:15:57)<the_ru>It's easy for me, though, since I know how it works
(09:16:07)<the_ru>Maybe it won't be as clear to the average player
(09:16:25)<the_ru>also, I'm testing stealth exclusively now
(09:16:45)<the_ru>I'm not sure how it works togenether with the other approaches you can take
(09:16:59)<the_ru>such as conjuring
(09:17:31)<the_ru>but I guess it would make sense to send your minions forth and then just hang around in the shadows

(02:00:15)<TMC>how far can you sneak from a dark tile and still be hidden?

(02:00:32)<the_ru>with 5 points, you can take 5 steps, basically
(02:01:03)<the_ru>speed also affects it - even if your 5 points have been spent, you might be able to get further before the enemies get to move again
(02:02:56)<the_ru>there are indirect rolls also
(02:03:23)<the_ru>for example when closing a door, you roll against your stealth skill to see how much noise you made
(02:03:32)<the_ru>if you closed it carefully, or just slammed it shut

(02:33:58)<the_ru>the machine isn't aware of control structures, those are just defined by the language to make things easier to read
(02:34:01)<TMC>for(;;) { switch (state) {
(02:34:06)<Kadwiell>Freebasic might do something crazy, though.. but it sounds really strange that switch would be a bottleneck
(02:34:20)<the_ru>isn't switch called select in basic?
(02:34:40)<TMC>case STATE_A; foobar; .... state = STATE_B;
(02:34:42)<TMC>etc }
(02:35:07)<TMC>i'm looking at the assembly produced by FB
(02:35:27)<TMC>anyway, can any compiler optimise that, in assembly, into

(02:36:24)<TMC>STATE_B: etc... }

(02:37:10)<Glowie>..I think?
(02:37:11)<TMC>it doesn't have "foobar;" either
(02:37:17)<the_ru>Glowie: no
(02:37:20)<the_ru>it doesn't even have if
(02:37:26)<the_ru>just conditional jumps

(02:38:35)<TMC>the faster it is, the better
(02:38:36)<the_ru>for example: if (b == 2) would translate to something like (pseudo-assembly): load b into register, reduce register by 2, if register is zero jump to section a, otherwise jump to section b
(02:38:41)<Glowie>True dat

(02:41:49)<TMC>	mov ecx, dword ptr [eax+8]

(09:21:39)<purestrain>with keyword, mixins, anonymous methods, foreach, getter/setter... everything i missed in c++
(09:29:10)<Kadwiell>Huh, the examples on Wikipedia don't look all that much like C++ - I think I'm too conservative for that :)
(09:31:21)<purestrain>oh, it is very familiar... i could almost copy / paste my c++ sources
(09:31:51)<purestrain>but compared to c++ it is really outstanding :-)
(09:31:57)<Kadwiell>Really? Perhaps just the superficial differences I'm noticing
(09:33:36)<Kadwiell>What do you mean by "getter/setter", anyway? Are they provided automatically?
(09:35:20)<purestrain>no, only syntactic sugar like Vec3d Position() { return position; }
(09:35:20)<purestrain>	Vec3d Position(Vec3d value) { return position = value; }
(09:37:59)<purestrain>the dark side of D are the many compiler bugs :-)
(09:39:24)<Kadwiell>Huh, not sure I understood your example.. can't you do that in C++, though perhaps you'd need an extra "const"?
(09:40:00)<Kadwiell>Compiler bugs, ouch - well, at least that becomes an occasionally-valid excuse for a buggy binary :)
(09:40:18)<purestrain>no; the above syntax allows me for something like: player.Position = .... instead of player.SetPosition(...)
(09:41:50)<Kadwiell>Ah, I see.. I don't think I've ever really felt a need for that
(09:42:08)<Kadwiell>Foreach sounds nice, though. Are there better string classes?

(08:41:04)<the_ru>when you click a button, the symbol you were thinking of is displayed

(09:07:02)<the_ru>I'm tweaking my dungeon generator
(09:07:11)<the_ru>I think I found an easier way to remove random walls
(09:13:34)<the_ru>(Thurston and Conway) An angel is stuck on an infinite sheet of graph paper, he can hop from square to adjacent square. Everytime the angel hops, the devil can knock out any square, so the angel can't ever go there. Can the devil trap the angel? What if the graph paper is a positive quadrant (i.e. is bounded on two sides).
(09:13:39)<the_ru>That sounds interesting
(09:20:57)<Kadwiell>No diagonal movement?
(09:21:10)<the_ru>I dunno
(09:21:16)<the_ru>I assumed it was allowed
(09:21:49)<Kadwiell>But Thurston and Conway may not have been familiar with roguelike conventions :)
(09:22:09)<the_ru>:-)
(09:22:46)<the_ru>I guess it gives extra points to calculate both variations, and see if it makes any difference :-)
(09:24:20)<Kadwiell>If there's no diagonal movement, I think the simplified version is very very trivial if you just play it out - e.g. make a knight's move in the same direction as the angel's first move, then move two squares ahead of the angel's next move, then the angel cannot prevent you from completing the diagonal, I think
(09:25:05)<Kadwiell>The game seems a bit like some parts of Go
(09:25:31)<the_ru>Hm
(09:25:39)<the_ru>But as always with mathematics, we need proof :-)
(09:26:09)<Kadwiell>Proof by exhaustion is valid if inelegant :)
(09:26:26)<the_ru>I disagree
(09:26:41)<the_ru>I think one should try to understand the problem at a deeper level
(09:27:02)<the_ru>I think I've removed almost all "exhaustive" algorithms in my code
(09:27:48)<Kadwiell>A noble sentiment, but "proof" has a specific logical meaning, satisfied by exhaustive techniques
(09:28:59)<the_ru>so what would you do, generate a list of all possible moves and counter-moves?
(09:29:00)<Kadwiell>I think this has irritated a few mathematicians, too, though.. if I remember correctly, the four-colour theorem was first proven in part by exhaustion
(09:29:43)<Kadwiell>The tree is very very small for the simplest case (positive quadrant only and no diagonal movement)
(09:29:57)<Kadwiell>Unless I'm misunderstanding some part of the problem
(09:30:15)<the_ru>ah
(09:30:27)<the_ru>well, I was thinking of all quadrants and diagonal movement :-)
(09:31:00)<the_ru>that could make an interesting mini-game in a roguelike, perhaps
(09:31:08)<the_ru>you have to seal the evil monster by outrunning it
(09:31:54)<Kadwiell>Hm, perhaps - does seem quite roguelike-y
(09:32:51)<the_ru>Hm hm
(09:33:01)<the_ru>Do you know the "divide rooms into smaller rooms" algorithm?
(09:33:10)<the_ru>I can't recall who I was discussing it with
(09:35:08)<Kadwiell>That would be splitting large rooms randomly either horizontally or vertically? I think I've used something along those lines
(09:35:14)<the_ru>yes
(09:35:37)<the_ru>I'm trying to create non-rectangular rooms
(09:36:09)<Kadwiell>And not just cheaply, i.e. by making nonrectangular shapes inside distinct rectangles?
(09:36:19)<the_ru>I've previously used an algorithm that selected a random wall and removed it
(09:36:25)<the_ru>So two rooms would be joined
(09:36:30)<the_ru>I'm trying to make it simpler
(09:36:49)<the_ru>What if instead of placing a door between two rooms, I place another tile that breaks the wall
(09:36:54)<the_ru>then I remove all "loose" wall ends
(09:37:28)<Kadwiell>Isn't that basically the same thing as removing a random wall?
(09:37:36)<Kadwiell>Can't see how it would be less complex
(09:37:44)<the_ru>Well, it needs less code
(09:38:02)<the_ru>and it feels like it gives me greater control over how many and which walls are removed
(09:38:16)<Kadwiell>Sounds like a good idea then :)
(09:39:22)<the_ru>what if I just generate rectangles, but flag each tile upon generation
(09:39:39)<the_ru>then pick a random door/wall, remove it
(09:39:54)<the_ru>and "unflag" all tiles in the adjacent rooms by floodfill
(09:40:20)<the_ru>a random door/wall adjacent to a flagged room, that is
(09:40:55)<the_ru>if I let it run to the finish, there ought to be no area on the map that is completely enclosed in walls
(09:43:00)<Kadwiell>Sounds correct.. but you may want a rectangular room now and again
(09:43:08)<Kadwiell>It's a pretty common shape for rooms to have :)
(09:43:18)<the_ru>Yes, but I'll limit the number of floodfills
(09:43:33)<the_ru>Right now I'm experimenting with letting it split rooms until they are 1-2 tiles wide and high, then remove a very high percentage of the doors
(09:44:09)<the_ru>It gives a lot of interesting room shapes, but also lots of 1-2 tile "closets" inbetween
(09:45:50)<the_ru>There are just too many doors
(09:46:07)<Kadwiell>Huh, that sounds like a weird way to use that algorithm
(09:46:17)<Kadwiell>Do you have a screenshot of the shapes you get from that?
(09:46:19)<the_ru>But if I set the door removal probability any higher, I fear I will just create large open spaces
(09:46:24)<the_ru>Wait
(09:47:22)<xJabberwocky>I'm interested to see as well
(09:48:10)<the_ru>http://www.eagle.y.se/~ru/pub/0.10-rooms.png
(09:49:14)<the_ru>I really wonder about the sanity of the architect though :-O
(09:50:03)<the_ru>the problem is; the more rooms that merge, the longer the walls get.
(09:50:16)<the_ru>so the more walls I remove, the quicker the rooms get bigger and bigger
(09:50:17)<xJabberwocky>looks almost diablo I ish
(09:50:27)<xJabberwocky>with the closets being the cages
(09:50:36)<Kadwiell>Yeah, that's not bad
(09:51:10)<the_ru>that's with ~75% doors/walls removed, BTW
(09:51:32)<Kadwiell>Very narrow spaces dominate, but that's the norm in corridors anyway
(09:51:51)<the_ru>well
(09:52:00)<the_ru>if they were *corridors* it would be ok
(09:52:15)<Kadwiell>But the L-shaped room on the lower left, for example, is a bit harsh
(09:52:19)<the_ru>perhaps if I'd remove the majority of the door connecting 1-tile wide spaces?
(09:52:35)<the_ru>yes
(09:53:23)<the_ru>perhaps I can tweak it by having different probabilities for y/x
(09:55:01)<the_ru>it's just that when I get to placing the doors, the two rectangles have already been built
(09:55:07)<the_ru>and can contain other rectangles
(09:55:23)<the_ru>so there's no trivial way for me to check which ones are 1-tile corridors
(09:56:37)<the_ru>perhaps if I search the map for floor tiles without neighbours?
(09:56:39)<the_ru>then punch a hole through a random wall?
(09:56:50)<the_ru>that should remove most of the closets, I imagine
(09:57:34)<the_ru>or I could fill them, making them 3x3 sections of wall
(09:58:02)<the_ru>that could result in disjoint areas, though, since the only door connecting two areas could be there
(09:59:47)<Kadwiell>Hm, it seems the Angel is meant to move diagonally
(10:00:04)<the_ru>only?

(10:17:07)<the_ru>http://www.eagle.y.se/~ru/pub/0.10-gca.png
(10:17:27)<the_ru>I'm writing a system for "graphical entities"
(10:17:58)<the_ru>that is then translated into a ncurses character + color pair + attributes
(10:19:19)<the_ru>so for example a ghoul only needs to specify it wants to be displayed as a ghoul, and doesn't have to care beyond that
(10:19:37)<the_ru>then it's up to the UI to decide if it should be displayed as a Z, a bitmap or a 3D model...
(10:19:45)<the_ru>I only care about the first case though
(10:22:17)<the_ru>(I guess most RLs already have this)

(02:13:35)<the_ru>what if I let the player go back in time, and be the hero in the old days as well?

(02:16:27)<the_ru>so when you go there in present day, it will be just like you left it

(06:19:00)<Aerton>although, I wonder if I can make a Mordheim game ^^
(06:19:15)<Aerton>the rules are freely available to download
(07:45:47)<segfault1>Slashdot told me that game rules can't be copyrighted, only the text describing them can.
(08:49:33)<RotateMe>hmmm you sure this applies for computer games too?
(08:50:02)<RotateMe>i heard that nintendo copyrighted the mechanic for super mario world style level maps
(08:54:10)<the_ru>huh
(08:54:25)<the_ru>there's a huge difference between copyright and patent
(08:55:14)<the_ru>obviously Nintendo own the copyright for the code of Super Mario World
(08:55:36)<the_ru>so redistribution of it without permission would be illegal
(08:55:56)<the_ru>still, it's just that specific implementation
(08:56:13)<the_ru>a patent, OTOH, describes an *idea* and forbids others from using it
(08:58:35)<the_ru>there's also plagiarism, where you make something so similar to something else that it's obviously "stolen"
(08:59:37)<the_ru>i.e. a platform game about a plumber called Mario would violate Nintendo trademarks, even if it doesn't use content made by Nintendo
(09:39:12)<the_ru>http://www.eagle.y.se/~ru/files/tsl-0.10.tar.gz

(05:15:41)<the_ru>now I just need to figure out how to deal with keypads
(05:16:38)<Aerton>it should not be a problem, ncurses recognises their sequences for you
(05:17:00)<the_ru>not here :-/
(05:17:12)<the_ru>I'm writing a test program right now to figure out what happens
(05:18:49)<Aerton>IIRC, you should call some function to enable recognition
(05:18:54)<the_ru>keypad(), yes
(05:20:43)<the_ru>hm hm
(05:21:06)<the_ru>they give > 255 values for getch()
(05:21:20)<the_ru>but they're not the same as in ncurses.h
(05:22:01)<the_ru>e.g. up gives 259, but ncurses.h says 403
(05:23:16)<Aerton>hmm
(05:23:43)<the_ru>and some keys give multiple bytes
(05:23:55)<the_ru>gives 27 79 111
(05:23:58)<the_ru>/ gives 27 79 111
(05:24:23)<Aerton>0403 == 259
(05:24:43)<the_ru>what? is it octal?
(05:24:52)<Aerton>yes
(05:25:30)<the_ru>a-ha
(05:25:33)<the_ru>well, that explains a lot
(05:26:21)<Aerton>cursor and other keys do send multiple codes, but curses should translate them according to the current terminal type
(05:26:42)<the_ru>I guess / on the numpad is an unknown escape sequence then
(05:26:48)<the_ru>considering the 27
(05:27:49)<Aerton>perhaps
(05:27:52)<Aerton>27 is escape
(05:28:01)<Aerton>it starts all these sequences
(05:28:09)<the_ru>yes
(05:28:17)<the_ru>so I suppose ncurses doesn't understand that particular one
(05:28:41)<the_ru>but anyway; it works now
(05:29:06)<the_ru>my "bindn" config directive can bind the KEY_* constants
(05:29:14)<the_ru>but how portable is it?
(05:29:44)<the_ru>it *should* be very portable, as long as the same ncurses version is used
(05:29:45)<the_ru>I guess.
(05:30:00)<the_ru>that's what I do mostly, guess :-)
(05:30:54)<Aerton>ncurses does not seem to change rapidly
(05:31:28)<Aerton>although, there are other curses implementations
(05:31:46)<Aerton>but I think these constants should be common, save for some exotic keys
(05:43:47)<the_ru>the constants should be safe to use, I think
(05:43:56)<the_ru>since ncurses sets them
(05:44:23)<the_ru>I think a bigger worry is if ncurses will be able to translate all kinds of sequences from weird terminals into those constants
(05:44:44)<the_ru>but that's far beyond anything I can do
(05:44:58)<the_ru>except manually parsing sequences, of course :-)
(05:46:47)<the_ru>and I doubt anyone needs to map things to odd keys anyway
(05:47:22)<the_ru>with keypad, letters (+uppercase), numbers there ought to be enough (normal) keys for anyone

(12:51:08)<the_ru>My new shield system isn't working as well as expected
(01:00:57)<oeb>How are you handling them?
(01:01:12)<oeb>% chance of deflecting or lesening the attack?
(01:01:32)<the_ru>you have a number of block points
(01:01:38)<the_ru>typically 3-5 or so
(01:01:42)<the_ru>they act as a HP buffer
(01:01:51)<oeb>From sheild related skills and type of shild?
(01:01:53)<the_ru>when you take damage, they are first taken from your shield
(01:01:59)<the_ru>yes
(01:02:06)<the_ru>bigger shields = more points, etc
(01:02:06)<oeb>So if I take 8 points damage, sheild removes three, I take 5?
(01:02:13)<the_ru>yes
(01:02:21)<oeb>Will the sheild do this every time? Or do they break?
(01:02:40)<oeb>Also, why is it not working? Just not effective?
(01:03:05)<the_ru>well; the shield points are depleted
(01:03:29)<the_ru>you have to regain them by waiting a turn
(01:03:41)<the_ru>to represent the concentration it takes to keep the shield up
(01:03:46)<oeb>An alternate method might be as follows. There is a block % gained through the skill and modified for larger sheilds. If you have directional damage this only applies to the front.
(01:04:00)<the_ru>that's what I used earlier
(01:04:04)<the_ru>(except directional damage)
(01:04:14)<oeb>Each sheild then has a % chance of blocking the attack completely, otherwise you take a % of the damage
(01:04:15)<the_ru>but I wanted it to be more interactive
(01:04:53)<the_ru>e.g. a 50% blocking shield will just halve the damage you take
(01:05:05)<the_ru>there's no *player* skill involved
(01:05:12)<oeb>Not using the method suggested above
(01:05:40)<oeb>a 50% blocking shild may be 70% for someone who specialised in sheilds to make a tank fighter
(01:05:52)<oeb>Or may be 30% in another.
(01:05:58)<the_ru>yeah, but it's still just something you put on
(01:06:07)<the_ru>I want to create more tension
(01:06:17)<oeb>I think you might be in danger of over complicating things.
(01:06:24)<the_ru>probably
(01:06:27)<oeb>Fight rest fight rest fight rest.
(01:06:52)<the_ru>the idea was that you could fight like a coward and just rest all the time
(01:07:00)<oeb>I think micromanagement like that would create the posibility of a tedious roguelike. That's just my opinion though.
(01:07:12)<the_ru>if you have good enough shield skill, you could avoid getting hurt at all
(01:07:19)<oeb>An alternate method to that could be to have a users AC vary over time.
(01:08:00)<the_ru>the problem is: the "Block" bar is either empty, giving the player very little feedback on how much was actually blocked, or too full, that no enemies succeed in hurting you at all
(01:08:23)<the_ru>but, how about a compromise
(01:08:42)<the_ru>shields have both a block percentage and a number of uses
(01:09:03)<oeb>Just give them a smash chance on succesful block.
(01:09:06)<the_ru>a medium-sized shield could have 2 uses and 40% block
(01:09:51)<oeb>It's a bit too black and white that way.
(01:09:55)<the_ru>if you have uses left, and roll below the block percentage, you block
(01:10:05)<the_ru>but for each successful block, you lose one use
(01:10:16)<the_ru>that you then have to regain by waiting
(01:10:39)<oeb>Should the wait not apply to all armour thought?
(01:10:53)<the_ru>why?
(01:11:06)<the_ru>you just wear the armor, but the shield takes some skill to use

(01:11:19)<oeb>You don't just stand there and take hits.
(01:11:32)<oeb>If you are tired, even in full plate you are easier to take down.

(01:07:43)<deveah>i find it difficult to make a split-rooms algorithm
(01:07:51)<the_ru>why?
(01:07:59)<deveah>dunno

(01:08:14)<the_ru>a-ha
(01:08:21)<the_ru>what's wrong, then?
(01:08:32)<deveah>i use something like this:
(01:08:41)<deveah>1. make base shape (of level)
(01:09:02)<deveah>2. pick random x and y vars, and another e var (end position)
(01:09:53)<deveah>3. if there isn't a wall on position x,y or on position x,e (for vertical) / e,y (horizontal), jump back to step 2
(01:10:12)<deveah>4. if it's ok, make a line of walls using the good coordinates
(01:10:20)<the_ru>you're doing it wrong
(01:10:25)<deveah>:/
(01:10:26)<the_ru>the key is proper use of recursion
(01:11:06)<the_ru>make a function that takes a coordinate pair and a length in each direction
(01:11:10)<the_ru>like t, l, h, w
(01:11:30)<the_ru>then you split either h or w in two, and call the function again
(01:11:56)<the_ru>that way, you'll always know what area you're allowed to build on
(01:12:14)<the_ru>once you get to the desired room size (5x5?), you clear that area to floor tiles, and return
(01:12:22)<deveah>as a c++ n00b, i might ask what should i compile - .h or .c files?
(01:12:28)<TMC>.c
(01:12:31)<deveah>oh
(01:12:32)<deveah>thanks

(01:14:12)<TMC>hehehe
(01:14:24)<TMC>shouldn't you include .c files from other .c files?
(01:14:50)<the_ru>why?
(01:15:26)<TMC>...something about object code
(01:15:26)<the_ru>you should be able to compile each .c file separately - the things that need to be shared between them should be in the headers
(01:15:48)<the_ru>then it's up to the linker to figure out how to put them together

(04:05:05)<RotateMe>i had a string i edit it, then i wanted it to pass to printleft which requires a const char *
(04:05:09)<the_ru>I try to use const as much as possible for function parameters
(04:05:38)<RotateMe>i wanted to do this in two steps, using a char * tmpLine which i filled with my string.c_str()
(04:05:50)<RotateMe>that didn't work because c_str() returns a const char *
(04:06:01)<RotateMe>so i redefined it, and the mess was perfect
(04:06:26)<the_ru>consts are IMO only really useful as function parameters
(04:06:35)<RotateMe>now i just use printLeft(myString.c_str());
(04:06:55)<the_ru>they guarantee that the data won't be modified
(04:07:10)<the_ru>(well, you can do an explicit const -> non-const cast, but that's really bad practice)
(04:07:13)<RotateMe>i don't think they're useful at all but you might now see how the compiler brought me into using it
(04:07:48)<RotateMe>i don't understand why c_str returns a const char
(04:07:49)<the_ru>they're useful when you have functions that only check things without changing them
(04:08:15)<RotateMe>well then i use pass by value
(04:08:15)<the_ru>if you declare a parameter const, the compiler will catch unintentional modifications
(04:08:26)<the_ru>such as a = being mistaken for ==
(04:08:46)<RotateMe>hmm right, that might come in handy
(04:09:05)<RotateMe>but like i said, the whole string stuff in c(++) is shit imo
(04:09:58)<the_ru>it also works downstream - if you have a const parameter, you can't pass it to another non-const function without the compiler complaining
(04:10:11)<the_ru>it really helps control where data goes and where it's modified
(04:10:23)<the_ru>why use C++ strings?
(04:10:30)<the_ru>C strings do all I need them to
(04:10:58)<RotateMe>what are c strings?

(04:28:06)<Kadwiell>strtok in particular is a rather weird function though, I've reimplemented that before just because I found the original inelegant
(04:33:16)<the_ru>the biggest problem is that it trashes the original string
(04:33:59)<the_ru>but my point was; for basic things, there's usually a function already that does it good enough
(04:34:34)<Aerton>strtok() is quite a hackish thing
(04:34:57)<Aerton>never understood how did it find it's way into standard
(04:35:35)<the_ru>still, if you just need it one time, it's faster to learn to work around its shortcoming than to develop your own
(04:36:23)<Aerton>it's not that flexible
(04:36:53)<the_ru>flexible enough to parse files
(04:38:08)<Aerton>some other standard functions are too strange at time... like WTF strncpy() does not close string with 0?
(04:38:35)<the_ru>what if I want to copy something into a "form"?
(04:39:41)<Kadwiell>There's also gets(), which I believe is absolutely impossible to use safely
(04:39:58)<Kadwiell>Seems they weren't very picky about what got into the standard..
(04:40:30)<the_ru>BUGS
(04:40:30)<the_ru>       Never use gets().  Because it is impossible to tell without knowing the
(04:40:30)<the_ru>       data in advance how many  characters  gets()  will  read,  and  because
(04:40:30)<the_ru>       gets() will continue to store characters past the end of the buffer, it
(04:40:30)<the_ru>       is extremely dangerous to use.  It has  been  used  to  break  computer
(04:40:32)<the_ru>       security.  Use fgets() instead.
(04:40:40)<Aerton>well, it can be needed sometimes, but the most common usage case would be to just copy a string, and there is simply no convenient routine for that
(04:41:02)<Aerton>(snprintf does not count)
(04:41:10)<the_ru>strdup?
(04:41:32)<Aerton>spare me...
(04:41:50)<Aerton>it's not even close
(04:42:02)<the_ru>I dunno what you want to do
(04:42:17)<Aerton>safely copy one string to another
(04:43:43)<the_ru>so what's wrong with strncpy?
(04:43:47)<the_ru>you *know* where it ends
(04:44:03)<Aerton>you have to write 0 yourself
(04:44:30)<the_ru>so create a mystrncpy() that does it for you
(04:45:51)<Aerton>one could expect to find such a simple and commonly needed thing among standard functions
(04:46:18)<Aerton>I bet, it's needed much more often than obscurities like aforementioned strtok()
(04:46:20)<the_ru>yeah, I get your point
(04:46:49)<the_ru>but why this came up is because many C++ books fail to mention the standard library
(04:47:14)<the_ru>they quickly jump into classes, pointers, inheritance - but rarely say how to actually get anything *done*
(04:47:49)<Aerton>these aren't good books
(04:48:18)<Aerton>or simply old books written before STL was included into the language standard
(04:48:55)<Kadwiell>I think perhaps he means that they do describe STL but not the "old" C features?
(04:49:02)<the_ru>yes
(04:49:15)<Kadwiell>Which is a problem mostly because some of the C++ things meant to replace them aren't very good
(04:49:16)<the_ru>and it's hard to tell as a newbie what books are good :-)
(04:49:41)<Kadwiell>Notably the string class, in my opinion, and also streams
(04:49:48)<the_ru>well, as you probably know I'm using C myself
(04:49:55)<the_ru>I don't really see the need to go C++
(04:50:30)<the_ru>Java has much of the same problem as well
(04:50:34)<the_ru>Like file I/O
(04:51:01)<the_ru>it's powerful once you know how it works, but it's hard to get something done in the beginning
(04:51:23)<Glowie>STL isn't a good reason to go to C++?
(04:51:38)<Aerton>well, much of the C routines are considered obsolete and their usage is discouraged in c++
(04:52:09)<Aerton>although, C++ "streams" are one big WTF
(04:52:38)<Kadwiell>Yeah, but sprintf is so much easier than the ostringstream stuff, for example
(04:53:43)<Kadwiell>So it doesn't matter too much that sprintf is "considered obsolete", if it's superior in practice
(04:54:36)<the_ru>I think most of the things that differ between C and C++ require some experience
(04:54:47)<the_ru>to understand when, and especially when not, to use them
(04:57:08)<the_ru>operator overloading, is it necessary?
(04:57:16)<the_ru>Java doesn't have them and I never missed them
(04:57:43)<Aerton>it's double-edged
(04:58:15)<Aerton>it's convenient when you can write vector or matrix math with + and *
(04:58:50)<Aerton>but it can be abused easily and too often
(04:59:03)<the_ru>but wouldn't a matrixAdd() do the same thing?
(04:59:24)<the_ru>or rather; be the same thing, but with a different name
(04:59:47)<Aerton>it would, but not so clearly and it would look different from notation in a math book
(04:59:55)<the_ru>but then even Java cheats a bit by allowing + for string concatenation
(05:01:03)<Kadwiell>True, I'd have liked the Java approach more if it actually was consistent
(05:02:17)<the_ru>Aerton: does it really matter? very little looks the same as in a math book
(05:02:27)<the_ru>i.e. everything beyond +-*/()
(05:02:37)<the_ru>%

(05:48:07)<Fobbah>basically i'll build a list of rooms one at a time, then as each new room is placed, select a room at random, and try to path a line from it to the new room that doesnt touch any clear squares
(05:48:25)<Fobbah>hex grid has its ups and downs
(05:48:29)<jraregris>yeah
(05:48:38)<jraregris>you can't have straight walls, for instance
(05:48:43)<Fobbah>the big positive is you can have round LOS thats actually true in terms of movement
(05:48:58)<jraregris>i thought of a way to improve hex
(05:49:25)<jraregris>you can divide a hex into six triangles
(05:50:43)<Fobbah>the idea being?
(05:50:53)<Fobbah>just higher resolution?
(05:50:58)<jraregris>yes
(05:51:34)<jraregris>you could have the character still fill the "old" hex, and then you could move "half a square"
(05:52:17)<jraregris>you could have monsters in different sizes that would actually have an impact on geometry
(05:52:54)<jraregris>i realise that this is very ambtious, and it's pretty far into the horizion for me

(04:39:19)<oeb>In the towns there are warehouses
(04:39:40)<oeb>Got everything a rougelike should have instadeth, random dungeons etc.
(04:40:28)<oeb>How a warehouse works is as follows, if I find an item, lets say a +5 katana this game, I can if I wish leave it in a warehouse.
(04:40:46)<oeb>I can give up the opertuinity to use it in this game to use it in a later one instead.
(04:41:22)<oeb>There are also items called warehouse jars. If I put an item into one of them in vanishes and appears in the first warehouse.
(04:41:35)<oeb>So I can potentially save a good weapon when I die.
(04:41:53)<Fobbah>so basically you're building up an arsenal so eventually you can get through the game?
(04:41:58)<oeb>It makes the game a bit less punishing and therefore more newbie friendly I think.
(04:42:08)<oeb>No, lets say I have a +5 sword in warehouse one
(04:42:18)<oeb>If I take it out this game it's gone from the warehouse.
(04:42:23)<oeb>Even for the next one.
(04:43:10)<oeb>I can give up the opertunity of using an item now to use it later instead.
(04:43:29)<oeb>The magic system is nearly non existant. There are spells but all are in scroll form.
(04:44:09)<oeb>It is possible to find items that are not identified, items can be wear or use identified if they are equipment.
(04:44:15)<oeb>There is also an identify jar
(04:44:28)<oeb>Items are automaticly identified when you go into a town
(04:45:11)<oeb>If you dont eat you die, there are common roguelike themes such as invisible enemys cursed weapons and a polymorph minigame (kinda)
(04:45:34)<oeb>It is no where as complex as even powder, but I think that can be a good thing too.
(04:47:28)<Fobbah>sounds cool
(04:47:34)<Fobbah>shame i dont have a ds lol :P
(04:47:56)<Fobbah>but the world needs more portable roguelikes haha

(04:48:41)<oeb>I think when I died (My best char yet) there was 13 elementals in there =/

(05:59:27)<Fobbah>basic controls - 
(05:59:27)<Fobbah>numpad for movement 
(05:59:27)<Fobbah>> - down stairs 
(05:59:27)<Fobbah>< - up stairs 
(05:59:27)<Fobbah>f - fire ranged weapon 
(05:59:27)<Fobbah>r - reload weapon 
(05:59:29)<Fobbah>t - throw grenade 
(05:59:31)<Fobbah>g - pick up item 
(05:59:31)<joe6pack>maybe i'll nick some off of an old game myselg 
(05:59:34)<Fobbah>u - use item 
(05:59:35)<Fobbah>w - wield weapon/melee weapon 
(05:59:37)<Fobbah>e - unwield weapon/melee weapon 
(05:59:39)<Fobbah>s - wait for 1 turn 
(05:59:41)<Fobbah>x - spend attribute points 
(05:59:43)<Fobbah>z - cast spell
