(12:00:16)<Fobbah>i'm going to write up a dungeon generator that builds a list of rooms and uses A* to link them together
(12:00:34)<the_ru>I've been struggling with mine for a few months, so I guess I'm quite used to seeing its output :-)
(12:00:43)<the_ru>hm hm
(12:00:48)<the_ru>sounds sophisticated
(12:00:50)<Fobbah>but theres currently 3 different generators in there which i'll use for differnent levels
(12:00:59)<Fobbah>thats how nethack style dungeons are generated
(12:01:15)<the_ru>not always
(12:01:23)<Fobbah>usually they are
(12:01:45)<the_ru>I had such dungeons earlier, and I didn't have no A* :-)
(12:02:06)<the_ru>not that my brute force approach was better, though...
(12:02:09)<Fobbah>honestly, if you already have pathfinding built in, it doesnt sound any more difficult than writing the normal dungeon generator stuff.. you just kinda build a list of rooms without worrying about linking them up, try to link them all with A* and then remove any rooms found to be unreachable. piece of cake
(12:02:35)<Fobbah>so all you have to check for is if they intersect when placing them rather than being adjacent, and the pathfinding does the work for you
(12:03:02)<the_ru>m-hm
(12:03:17)<Fobbah>in fact it sounds easier than my current method of *search for wall* - *build out from wall*
(12:03:25)<the_ru>I started by building a room, then building corridors in random directions, etc
(12:04:02)<the_ru>I think I'm still using a horribly mutated version of that code actually
(12:04:19)<Fobbah>mine just needs a complete rewrite

(10:10:59)<the_ru>what do you think of hitpoints?
(10:11:18)<the_ru>I'm pondering giving my creatures a small number of them
(10:11:35)<the_ru>and let each attack take one HP
(10:12:01)<the_ru>then weapons would just have a to-hit modifier and not a damage score
(10:12:09)<the_ru>what problems will arise?
(10:14:29)<purestrain>try it
(10:14:56)<purestrain>but i don't think using only hit modifiers will be good
(10:24:31)<purestrain>also it means, you can get stronger and better, but a creature will always require 3 hits e.g.
(10:24:53)<the_ru>yes
(10:25:14)<the_ru>but I'm not sure how my weapons should work
(10:25:26)<the_ru>right now damage =
(10:25:36)<purestrain>traditional? just dealing with damage values ?
(10:25:42)<the_ru>damage = strength + weapon damage
(10:26:07)<the_ru>I want to keep them very low powered
(10:26:22)<the_ru>but they grow too powerful too fast
(10:27:00)<purestrain>what about e.g. damage = base_weapon_damage + (addition_weapon_damage / 10 * strength) ?
(10:27:02)<the_ru>i.e. unarmed = base damage 1, dagger = 2, sword/mace = 3
(10:27:43)<the_ru>I don't think fractions will work well, I'm using very small numbers
(10:27:47)<purestrain>could you tweak weapons with other attributes like armor penetration? knockout value?
(10:28:14)<the_ru>some have random effects, some have to-hit modifiers, all have speeds
(10:29:08)<the_ru>so weapons that do a lot of damage could maybe be balanced by being hard to hit with, and taking more time than a lighter weapon
(10:29:50)<the_ru>I dunno why I've been so fixated on discrete numbers lately :-/
(10:30:18)<purestrain>that are the things i hate... e.g. a realtime strategy game: you can build a battleship for $2000, but you could also build 20x smaller ones for each $100;
(10:30:45)<purestrain>both are balanced to win equally ;-)
(10:30:58)<purestrain>why should one weapon with high damage harder to hit ?
(10:31:09)<the_ru>because it's usually heavier
(10:31:30)<the_ru>a hammer or axe, for example
(10:31:59)<the_ru>swords and daggers allow more finesse, but don't hurt as much...
(10:32:02)<the_ru>or something
(10:32:25)<the_ru>ah, yes - weapon skill also modifies damage right now
(10:33:23)<the_ru>so with a mace (3), +1 strength and +2 mace skill, you'd do 6 points of damage at most
(10:34:03)<purestrain>hmm... if i'm a experiences sword fighter, should i deal more damage or should i hit more often?
(10:34:10)<the_ru>both
(10:34:21)<the_ru>perhaps I should just make powerful weapons more rare
(10:34:34)<purestrain>perhaps... perhaps i've got to go to bed now ;-)

(01:16:32)<oeb>I may have to take a stab at it.
(01:16:48)<oeb>I guess I get to work on the 15 steps tonight so.
(01:16:49)<Fobbah>but theres so much overhead in the g.drawString command in java's awt that i cant get more than 20-30 FPS which is pretty pathetic
(01:17:27)<Fobbah>doesnt hurt the game too mcuh but you do notice the sluggishness a little, doesnt feel as polished, and if you want to do any nice little animations its a pain
(01:17:56)<oeb>Aye
(01:20:26)<oeb>Hmmm, different gods could have different skill sets. For example the god of death might have an avatar with a rotting touch, who summons the villages own dead back to create havoc.
(01:24:02)<oeb>The god of war might be represented by a towering armored foe who takes less damage from attacks but has spells that are less descructive (Rain of arrows etc)
(01:24:35)<Fobbah>theres a lot of different ways you can run with it
(01:26:17)<oeb>I'm gonna have fun writing all these down and doing nothing with it =P
(01:27:57)<oeb>It's been years since I have even done any OO programming
(01:28:56)<Fobbah>in a roguelike you're going to be using a lot of OO if you want your code not to cough splutter and die after 2 days lol
(01:29:16)<oeb>Well java kinda forces you to be OO.
(01:29:40)<Fobbah>thats why its a good language for the job. not because of any explicit features but the way you tend to code in java
(01:30:22)<Fobbah>the trick lies in getting a good data structure set up, i base everything from a superclass and work from there using abstraction
(01:32:27)<Fobbah>a cool thing i came across in java lately is the serializable interface, it really saved me a lot of effort in terms of saving/loading
(01:33:31)<oeb>All I remember from interfaces is that they are a nice way to do something like, you have a map generator interface and then an implementation for wilderness, one for dungeons, one for mines etc.
(01:34:06)<Fobbah>well the serializable interface basically lets you take an object and output it in an objectoutputstream so you can save it directly to a file
(01:34:37)<Fobbah>you can designate classes as "transient" in their definition and it wont attempt to save them
(01:35:00)<oeb>much like serialize() works in PHP so.
(01:35:09)<Fobbah>so you have a top level class running the game, and the whole gamestate can be stored in one object, and its just a matter of saving it
(01:35:48)<Fobbah>whats more, while it winds up being about 500kb for my game atm, if you compress it in zip format, i can bring the size of the entire saved gamestate down to about 20kb
(01:36:11)<Fobbah>which is all the data and mobs from all the levels, as i pregenerate my dungeon
(01:36:41)<oeb>Ohh I'm looking forward to this now.
(01:36:45)<Fobbah>so i'll probably implement a library or whatever to compress the output, but all and all, its very nice and easy
(01:37:07)<Fobbah>literally this is my savegame function
(01:37:32)<Fobbah>FileOutputStream f_out = new FileOutputStream("./saves/" + pname + ".data");
(01:37:41)<Fobbah>ObjectOutputStream obj_out = new ObjectOutputStream(f_out);
(01:37:47)<Fobbah>obj_out.writeObject(hub);
(01:37:59)<Fobbah>System.exit(0);
(01:38:12)<Fobbah>and bam, the game is saved in 4 lines if you count shutting down the RL
(01:38:53)<oeb>So that basicially grabs the state of every object that's not transient?
(01:39:11)<Fobbah>yep
(01:39:20)<oeb>And saves it so you can I would assume readObject(); later?
(01:39:36)<oeb>That's a pretty damn simple way to handle it.
(01:40:02)<Fobbah>its pretty simple, i have to redefine a few things
(01:40:10)<Fobbah>but more or less you read the game object straight back in
(01:40:14)<Fobbah>with all of the data
(01:41:12)<Fobbah>hell i even save the JFrame and JPanel etc
(01:41:22)<Fobbah>works fine
(01:41:31)<Fobbah>tried moving the save file from system to system, no problems
(01:45:41)<oeb>Think my boss would notice if I opened up a JAVA IDE instead of ZEND?
(01:45:53)<oeb>Probably not I bet.

(09:27:54)<Fobbah>but this is what i came up with: http://img115.imageshack.us/img115/8708/effpathdungeonmp7.gif

(02:11:58)<the_ru>the majority of the 9000 different companies offering their services only do so in southern sweden
(02:12:08)<Fobbah>one company controls just about all the standard copper telephone lines, and by extension ADSL
(02:12:40)<Fobbah>the other has a fairly large cable tv network, and runs phone services through the same lines as their tv/internet
(02:13:20)<Fobbah>all the ADSL companies in australia buy access to the first company's network
(02:14:08)<Fobbah>but if you're outside the second company's network you're stuck paying the first company for phone line rental for any ADSL service, $20 a month for phone services you wont use
(02:14:33)<Fobbah>just for the connection itself, not paying for a realistic phone plan
(02:15:19)<Fobbah>if you want a proper landline you're looking at about $60 a month which is retardedly expensive

(11:26:32)<TMC>yeah, I suppose most of them are really bad rogue style room generators
(11:26:46)<TMC>or the same random caves everyone has
(11:26:48)<TMC>but even the good ones seem to be a lot simplier than what I'm doing...
(11:27:22)<Fobbah>only way ive been able to do decent dungeons is by generating a list of rooms first, then using pathfinding to plot corridors between them
(11:27:50)<Fobbah>all the ones ive seen are based on selecting a random wall on the map, then drawing out from there, which sounds like a good idea but doesnt really work well
(11:29:12)<Fobbah>also if you build a list of rooms, and select rooms from a not joined list and move them to a joined list as you successfully plot paths to them, you can actually very easily fill in any rooms which are isolated later

(04:36:26)<Kadwiell>In my experience, structures like linked lists are most useful when you need to be able to "grow" them dynamically, adding more members
(04:37:55)<Kadwiell>It's not a bad idea to use them in pathfinding("growing" a path), but I don't think you really need to have your map as a linked list of tiles, unless you have a very weird map structure
(04:51:59)<oeb[a]>I assumed you could kind of grow your path over your map. I have not implemented any kind of path finding yet, I just assumed it would be easier to calculate from lists than an array.
(04:52:39)<oeb[a]>Is the normal way it is done to generate a list that maps out your array and calculate them from that? If so what is the point in having both? Or am I getting all confused again.
(04:54:15)<Kadwiell>Well, if you look up A* on Wikipedia, you'll see references to things like queues and paths.. those are generally implemented by linking structures together
(04:54:30)<RotateMe>nope, the normal (a*) pathfinding has nodes which is kind of a linked list, but more like a tree structure
(04:55:08)<oeb[a]>I have had an article on a* recomended to me on a web site, Amit's game programming I think. It's on my reading list atm =)
(04:55:15)<RotateMe>it's like you said, it grows it over the map and when it reaches the target, you can go through the nodes backwards
(04:55:48)<RotateMe>there's not really much more to it when i think about it
(04:56:18)<RotateMe>some conditions when nodes die (like when the path is already longer than the shortest found) but that's about it
(04:56:51)<jraregris>If you make your map a LL you can get really dynamic about how the thing works
(04:56:52)<RotateMe>i'm currently doing a real-time strategy roguelike, a* will be too slow for this :(
(04:58:01)<RotateMe>yep, generating it as a linked list in the first place makes it VERY easy to do pathfinding, but you have to have a second structure on how to represent the map i guess
(04:58:27)<jraregris>Like if every cell has a east, west, north, south, up, down-pointers

(05:05:58)<Kadwiell>A* is too slow for your purposes?
(05:06:46)<oeb[a]>Would I be correct in saying pretty much all I need to do in c to make a linked list is stick a pointer in a structure to related lists?
(05:07:20)<Kadwiell>Yes, pretty much
(05:07:23)<Kadwiell>struct node {
(05:07:24)<oeb[a]>For example struct map { struct map *up; struck map *down; } etc
(05:07:27)<Kadwiell> int data;
(05:07:31)<Kadwiell> struct node *next;
(05:07:32)<Kadwiell>}
(05:08:18)<Kadwiell>The above is the "linked list" proper(though of course what sort of data you use is arbitrary.. many structures can be implemented with similar techniques
(05:08:26)<oeb[a]>Stand by for lots of me being confused and looking for help here later btw =P
(05:08:51)<Kadwiell>I think what you're describing is really a directed graph
(05:09:31)<oeb[a]>Is that another data structure?
(05:11:05)<Kadwiell>More of a mathematical concept, but add data to each vertex it'll be one, I guess
(05:11:11)<Kadwiell>*if you add
(05:11:45)<RotateMe>Kawdiell: I would think A* is too slow...
(05:11:58)<RotateMe>how many units on how big maps can it take?
(05:13:14)<Kadwiell>I think it's supposed to be pretty fast, but the memory usage can be bad
(05:13:46)<Kadwiell>But if you accept nonoptimal paths I suppose you can find them much faster
(05:14:57)<RotateMe>problem is, the map has much more free space then in most roguelikes... it's more like a strategy game map
(05:15:26)<oeb[a]>What alternitives are there to a*?
(05:16:22)<Kadwiell>RotateMe: Perhaps you could use "waypoints" to find a rough outline of an acceptable path?
(05:16:40)<Kadwiell>And then switch to full-detail pathfinding when you get close to your goal
(05:16:58)<RotateMe>yep i will do that
(05:17:25)<RotateMe>there are few spots where real good pathfinding is required and i could just stuff them with waypoints
(05:18:42)<Kadwiell>Like narrow passages and such?
(05:20:10)<Kadwiell>I always have problems with those, because I think they actually require more than good pathfinding - NPCs have to sometimes "cooperate", wait for their turn and get out of the way..
(05:20:58)<Kadwiell>In Tribe I ended up making all hallways very wide because of this, I think movement would otherwise be very annoying with all the nonhostile NPCs around
(05:22:16)<RotateMe>yep, but since my game is realtime it's not such a big problem, skipping their turn means just waiting 1 frame and try again

(11:48:20)<oeb_werk>Underneath each one you generate a small tunnel complex, and connect the complexes.

(08:53:21)<Glowie>Starting with a screen full of wall and creating the first room in a random place and start loop: 1. pick a suitable tile. 2. create random corridors, as many as you like. 3. create a room. Go to the beginning and loop through. Also add an overlapping check to kill unsuitable corridors and rooms at some point

(09:41:34)<oeb>A session
(09:41:37)<the_ru>first, you select a tuning
(09:41:41)<the_ru>that's stored in a cookie
(09:41:46)<oeb>Use sessions
(09:41:51)<oeb>They are easier to work with
(09:41:58)<the_ru>are they persistant?
(09:42:19)<oeb>Only for this session
(09:42:59)<the_ru>a normal cookie would actually be more useful then
(09:43:11)<the_ru>since it would remember for next time what tuning you use
(09:43:37)<oeb>(A session lasts until it is idle for a specific amount of times, normally 30 min, or until the browser closes)
(09:44:11)<oeb>Sessions are very like cookies, except only an id is stored on the users machine (In a cookie), all the information is stored on the server
(09:44:46)<the_ru>ok
(09:44:55)<the_ru>never bothered to learn to use them

(05:34:29)<greg>you have 2 solution : the easy -> you move your cam screen by screen, following the player and checking the bounding of the map
(05:34:55)<greg>the hard -> move the camera pixel by pixel to have smooth scroll

(09:12:01)<Kadwiell>* means "pointer" (in this context, anyway, if you meant void *)
(09:12:22)<jraregris>yeah
(09:12:37)<jraregris>my guess, actually.
(09:12:49)<RotateMe>purestrain: but the g-costs have to be in relation to the h-costs otherwise results will be likewise bad i think
(09:15:22)<purestrain>huh? why should they be in relation? o_O perhaps i'm thinking wrong...
(09:15:44)<Kadwiell>I haven't really thought this through deeply, but doesn't it make sense?
(09:15:58)<purestrain>but as for me, g could be anything, if you are moving over swamp, it could be 30, if you're moving over plains, it oculd be one
(09:16:28)<RotateMe>relation might be the wrong word but if you add 1 for every field you moved away from the start point, but add the squared costs of the distance to the target the results are wrong
(09:16:56)<RotateMe>purestrain: yes that's right, but the h costs take an average of those costs, in your example 15 * distance
(09:17:03)<Kadwiell>If we let distances approach infinity and h grows with the square of the distance, it makes sense that it ends up being the only thing considered..
(09:17:07)<purestrain>huh ?
(09:17:23)<purestrain>i'd never taken an average costs
(09:17:46)<RotateMe>just distance or what?
(09:18:10)<purestrain>perhaps i completely misunderstood the true concepts behind a* ;-)
(09:18:25)<RotateMe>g-costs and h-costs have the same worth in order to see if a knot is better than other knots
(09:19:27)<RotateMe>so if you just add one to g, but a squared value to the h-costs you end up with taking wrong knots as the best
(09:19:34)<Kadwiell>The multiplier for movement cost doesn't really matter here, as x^2 > Mx when x -> inf no matter what M is
(09:19:35)<RotateMe>which brings non optimal ways
(09:19:42)<purestrain>why ?
(09:20:13)<RotateMe>because taken distance is as important as distance to be taken
(09:21:12)<RotateMe>Kawdiell: the multiplier doesn't matter in that case but i'm saying that you SHOULDN'T use the x^2 <> Mx comparison
(09:21:38)<Kadwiell>You shouldn't use it in A*? Right, that's what I'm saying too
(09:21:44)<purestrain>rotateme, even so; it's just a heuristic
(09:22:00)<Kadwiell>Or are you saying that the math doesn't apply?
(09:22:11)<RotateMe>no, no, not use it in A*
(09:22:27)<RotateMe>purestrain, yes it is heuristic, but the better the estimation the better the results
(09:23:11)<RotateMe>and i don't think that taking the powered distances added and unsquared as the h-costs is not really better than using the manhatten way
(09:23:28)<purestrain>but even if i think more about it... i don't get the point
(09:24:13)<RotateMe>the point using manhatten?
(09:24:39)<RotateMe>or taking the squareroot distance as the h-costs?
(09:26:53)<Kadwiell>Oops, I think we've been overthinking this
(09:27:04)<Kadwiell>The appropriate heuristic isn't actually Euclidean
(09:27:22)<Kadwiell>But max(abs(dx),abs(dy))
(09:27:55)<RotateMe>oh... that sounds good
(09:27:59)<RotateMe>:D
(09:28:11)<RotateMe>where did you read this?
(09:28:13)<Kadwiell>I think this is because the costs for moving diagonally are "wrong" (i.e. not sqrt(2))
(09:28:26)<Kadwiell>One screen up from the link I pasted above
(09:28:31)<RotateMe>ah okay
(09:28:44)<RotateMe>yeah that's why i don't use euclidian
(09:28:48)<Kadwiell>E.g. f you want to move 10 north, 20 east, you move 10 northeast, then 10 east
(09:28:52)<Kadwiell>If*
(09:29:17)<RotateMe>ah okay that's right, makes perfect sense :D
(09:29:20)<RotateMe>thanks
(09:31:12)<purestrain>hmmm....
(09:32:02)<purestrain>afair my units always took the best path
(09:32:10)<purestrain>i should reimplement a* with d
(09:47:41)<purestrain>my brain is bumping... i'm thinking and thinking
(09:58:08)<purestrain>maybe i've already thought about it, and thats the reason why i used a integer square root :-)
(10:00:04)<RotateMe>the h-costs are meant to be nothing else then a good estimation of the steps you have to go to reach the target, BUT they should never be bigger than the actual way that you need to go there
(10:00:22)<RotateMe>MAX(dx,dy) is just the shortest way, with which you can't be wrong
(10:01:07)<RotateMe>if you would use the euclidian distance, you would assume that moving diagonally is more expensive than moving straight, which it isn't in most RLs
(10:01:20)<purestrain>but it is in mine
(10:04:01)<jraregris>neat
(10:05:32)<RotateMe>ah okay than the euclidian way is just right

(03:26:22)<RotateMe>ah, well that's what i'm trying to find out
(03:26:33)<TMCSleep>you know, this is hard to remember: but you really should always profile before doing serious optimisation
(03:26:57)<TMCSleep>but no matter how well you know your code, you will probably be amazed at where it's actually taking its time
(03:27:02)<TMCSleep>*because no matter
(03:27:14)<RotateMe>do you know whether code::blocks has a profiler built in?
(03:27:23)<TMCSleep>it uses gcc, right?
(03:27:30)<TMCSleep>gcc comes with gprof
(03:27:40)<RotateMe>okay
(03:27:52)<TMCSleep>you need to compile with a switch
(03:28:11)<RotateMe>ah okay
(03:28:19)<RotateMe>and how can i look into the results?
(03:29:04)<TMCSleep>look for the gprof manual (but don't read it too closely, most of it isn't helpful)
(03:29:16)<TMCSleep>ok, you compile with -g -pg
(03:29:22)<TMCSleep>then you run the program
(03:29:40)<TMCSleep>which generates a file, gmon.out
(03:29:53)<TMCSleep>you then run gprof on it to create a report
(03:30:14)<TMCSleep>there's two main reports it produces:
(03:30:35)<TMCSleep>one lists time spent per function, the other time spent per line of code
(03:31:32)<TMCSleep>gprof doesn't seem like the best profiler to me, but it's pretty quick to use
(03:32:19)<TMCSleep>(oh, I forgot that gprof can also do code block execution counting. That's not available in freebasic, where I've been using gprof)
(03:33:11)<TMCSleep>I don't know how well it works with C++ either; I've never tried
(03:37:14)<RotateMe>looking in the task manager proofs something is wrong: 50% cpu usage
(03:37:24)<RotateMe>since i have a dual core this is pretty bad :D
(03:37:34)<RotateMe>hmmm where did my gprof.out go?
(03:37:38)<TMCSleep>while playing?
(03:37:44)<TMCSleep>no idea :P
(03:37:45)<RotateMe>game directory or compiler directory?
(03:37:50)<RotateMe>yep while playing
(03:38:04)<TMCSleep>must be game directoru
(03:38:29)<TMCSleep>be warned that gcc/gprof doesn't pick up all the time spent in the program
(03:38:36)<TMCSleep>library functions might be ignored
(03:39:23)<TMCSleep>and things like class constructors might produce difficult to understand reports
(03:40:12)<RotateMe>hmm can't find it
(03:40:37)<RotateMe>i guess the program has to end returning 0

(04:09:54)<TMCSleep>it seems you have to link with libc_p.a
(04:10:18)<TMCSleep>wait
(04:10:32)<TMCSleep>well, you need to change your linking options
(04:11:19)<TMCSleep>something to the effect of
(04:11:25)<TMCSleep>ld -o myprog /lib/gcrt0.o myprog.o -lc_p
(04:13:08)<TMCSleep>it gets the times (in windows only I think) by running a thread which checks the current execution position every timer interrupt

(03:43:13)<the_ru>never mind

(03:44:04)<the_ru>THE   VARIABLE    =    thevariAbLE++;
(03:45:20)<the_ru>I just don't see the point - a strict compiler is one of the few tools we have when we program, and you want to make them less useful?
(03:54:19)<Kadwiell>I guess it would make it easier to, say, communicate code correctly over the phone
(03:54:32)<Kadwiell>Which for all we know may be an important requirement :)
(04:08:50)<TMC2>no, it's an existing scripting language
(04:08:59)<TMC2>I'm writing a code formatter for it
(04:09:31)<TMC2>it doesn't look foreign
(04:09:56)<TMC2>if (flag == true) then (do battle (battle: boss battle))
(04:11:04)<TMC2>unfortunately, I was pressured to implement allowing whitespace in the middle of operators (like '= =') too
(04:12:08)<TMC2>which you might want to do (if you were used to throwing whitespace everywhere) in one case:
(04:12:26)<TMC2>$ id= "asfagg"
(04:12:32)<TMC2>(where =" is an operator)
(04:12:49)<TMC2>or  $id = "asdasdjs"
(04:13:08)<TMC2>ok it's not really an operator

(04:46:27)<TMC2>no, it's hamsterspeak
(04:47:14)<TMC2>a pretty primitive language that doesn't fulling support strings: the $ is a hack string construct
(04:47:21)<TMC2>*fully
(04:48:13)<TMC2>maybe its inspired by pascal, since it has begin and end

(01:16:57)<Mingos>My dungeon generator needs nearly a second to make a dungeon... Imagine Java, which is roughly 10 times slower...

(01:18:59)<Mingos>besides, I simply can't get used to using classes for everything
(01:19:38)<Mingos>I prefer global variables, functions and that sort of stuff
(01:20:03)<Mingos>I used it as a kid in my first simple programs 10 years ago and it still works fine :)
(01:20:49)<Mingos>And I was unable to run any Java program from outside the compiler... it gave me weird errors within the main class
(01:21:17)<Mingos>Still, my game doesn't run on all computers either
(01:21:37)<Kadwiell>I think most of the slowness of Java comes from having to load large parts of the class library before doing even pretty simple stuff
(01:21:43)<Mingos>My girlfriend's notebook appears to be unable to run TCODlib-powered programs...
(01:22:05)<Mingos>dunno why
(01:22:07)<Kadwiell>So for things that are slow because they require a lot of calculation (like dungeon generation), it's not so much worse..
(01:23:12)<Mingos>Well, it may be so, but I *still* prefer to stick to C :)
(01:23:59)<jomiolto>hmm, it might be interesting to make a roguelike in assembler...
(01:24:07)<jomiolto>I haven't done any real asm coding for a way too long time

(01:24:49)<Mingos>ASM RL... a pain in the arse to make, but real fun to play, right?
(01:25:16)<Kadwiell>I'm not sure it would automatically be more fun to play :)
(01:25:28)<Mingos>Due to its speed, I mean
(01:25:43)<Kadwiell>But it would be a nice exercise
(01:25:48)<jomiolto>I doubt I could make faster asm code than what modern compilers generate...
(01:26:09)<Mingos>ASM is as close to the processor's "language" as it gets, so it would be fast as hell
(01:26:11)<jomiolto>but the tiny executable would be fun :)
(01:26:24)<Mingos>aye, the executables are small indeed
(01:26:48)<jomiolto>perhaps one day I should make a 4kB roguelike as a 7drl :)
(01:27:45)<jomiolto>Mingos: modern compilers actually generate faster code than what most assembler coders could make themselves
(01:28:25)<Mingos>possibly, I don't know ASM :)
(01:28:29)<jomiolto>sometimes when I debug some code generated by gcc (with optimizations on) I'm quite amazed at some of the tricks the compiler does
(01:28:43)<Mingos>such as?
(01:29:17)<jomiolto>like using some special instructions to avoid doing a multiplication (which is slow)
(01:29:29)<Mingos>interesting...
(01:30:02)<Mingos>division seems to be slower, that's why i prefer to multiply by a fraction :)
(01:30:28)<Mingos>dunno if it's faster, but I feel better doing so
(01:30:36)<Kadwiell>I think the compiler optimizes that away at least
(01:30:54)<Kadwiell>If you mean dividing by a constant float/double
(01:31:00)<jomiolto>a multiplication by a power of two can be easily optimized to a bit shift, but numbers that are not powers of two are a bit more difficult
(01:31:16)<jomiolto>bah, who uses floating point? :P
(01:31:29)<jomiolto>integers should be enough for everybody :)
(01:31:39)<Mingos>I do... sometimes at least, despite its limitations and weird behaviour...
(01:31:51)<Mingos>they're handy
(01:32:27)<jomiolto>I don't know why, but for some reason I've always disliked using floating for anything that doesn't necessarily require it
(01:32:36)<Mingos>but I try to use ints whenever possible
(01:32:37)<jomiolto>I wonder if I should have therapy for it?
(01:32:50)<jomiolto>:P
(01:32:51)<Mingos>definitely not
(01:32:57)<Kadwiell>I dislike it in theory, but I need the square root of two or something and everything just becomes much easier with doubles
(01:33:02)<Mingos>floats are inaccurate
(01:33:07)<Kadwiell>then I*
(01:33:28)<Mingos>but still come in handy
(01:34:03)<Kadwiell>Floats are inaccurate, but if you want to deal with nonintegers at all conceptually speaking, you need inaccuracy
(01:34:15)<Mingos>I've a colour modification function based on TCODlib's HSB functions. It can use ints, but requires extra calculations
(01:34:22)<Kadwiell>Otherwise you're using a "Rational" class for everything, and I've been down that road :)
(01:34:29)<Mingos>When I switched to floats, things got faster
(01:35:47)<Mingos>Kadwiell, I had an issue with floats' inaccuracy that made me realize it's better to use ints then it's possible
(01:36:02)<_df_>floats are bad mmm kay
(01:36:39)<jomiolto>it's actually amazing how many algorithms can be adapted to work with pure integers and still give the same accuracy (or even better) as using floating point would give
(01:36:49)<Mingos>they're bad in some situations, but good in others
(01:37:08)<Mingos>exactly, jomiolto, exactly.
(01:37:17)<_df_>most arm cores dont have fpu.. (eg: porting to GP2X)..
(01:37:33)<_df_>so floats really kill you with the soft fpu in software
(01:37:48)<Mingos>and more speed as well, since logical operations on ints are faster than on floats :)
(01:37:52)<jomiolto>Bresenham's algorithms compared to naive line/circle algorithms are a good example of that
(01:38:07)<Kadwiell>Yep, there's Bresenham, and most angle-related stuff on a grid at least
(01:38:27)<Kadwiell>Requires a bit more thinking time to write it that way, though, at least for me
(01:38:43)<jomiolto>I don't know if people usually use floating point for shadow casting, but I adapted it to work with integers and still be precise :)
(01:38:44)<Mingos>There's my Dijkstra's modification that uses ints and gets the same results :)
(01:39:09)<Mingos>With floats, it entered an infinite loop due to its inaccuracies
(01:40:14)<Mingos>now, using only logical additions and ints instead of floats, it's blazing fast and 100% accurate
(01:40:58)<Mingos>and no graph theory involved :)

(07:48:34)<Mingos>hmm, Ive just found out that using "if"s constantly is faster than "if"-"else if"-"else if"... I thought it should be the other way round...
(07:49:15)<TMC2>whaaaat
(07:49:55)<TMC2>it must be the other way around
(07:50:33)<TMC2>a chain of else if's is equivalent to a goto theend; in each if block
(07:50:54)<deveah>i know the same
(07:51:07)<deveah>who said that?
(07:51:25)<TMC2>but when optimising code, I've noticed that random changes can have a large surprising effect of the speed of a block of code
(07:52:02)<deveah>using, say a 1000 rnd's, will slow down A LOT my code?
(07:52:28)<Mingos>I thought it would be the other way round as well, but a 25 second test of an algorithm that is almost 100% ifs seems to run faster than with if-elses...
(07:52:44)<deveah>i'm trying to make "Randomfight0rz", an ASCII top-down view randombased space shooter
(07:52:50)<TMC2>writing my own random function was vastly faster than usint the crt rand(), even though it produced the same numbers
(07:53:02)<TMC2>I guess there is a lot of overhead in library calls?
(07:53:09)<TMC2>I don't know anything about ABI's, etc
(07:53:38)<TMC2>the ifs are all mutually exclusive?
(07:53:57)<Mingos>Yes, that's why I used if-elses
(07:54:06)<Mingos>and the stuff slowed down!

(07:54:31)<TMC2>did you change the order at all? I suppose not
(07:54:40)<Mingos>no... why?
(07:54:48)<TMC2>it could be something to do with the optimiser

(07:56:34)<TMC2>even modern C compilers are bad at optimising code compared to humans
(07:57:15)<Mingos>Umm... you mean VS has automatical code optimisation?
(07:57:21)<TMC2>for instance, C++ is designed so that writting the same code with lots OO techniques, and it pure C, should compile to the same assembly if not doing anything fancy
(07:57:51)<TMC2>but in reality, the C++ code is often waaay slower because an enormous amount of compiler optimisation would be required :(

(05:46:25)<joe6pack>:)
(05:46:37)<joe6pack>which algorithm are you using?
(05:48:08)<RotateMe>A* with binary heaps
(05:48:25)<RotateMe>assisted by waypoints
(05:48:36)<RotateMe>on a 250x250 map
(05:48:53)<joe6pack> assisted by waypoints?
(05:48:55)<joe6pack>what do you mean
(05:53:51)<RotateMe>units nead to move across the whole map, but this would cost pretty much time at once, so i put waypoints all over the map which units use as temporary targets
(05:54:16)<joe6pack>oh ok
(05:54:35)<RotateMe>one waypoint points to two waypoints which are nearer to any of the two "camps"
(05:54:50)<RotateMe>(and i'm currently implementing forks)
+++ The date has changed: 2008/06/08 +++
(12:43:07)<Kadwiell>Hmm, not sure I understand how you're doing the pathfinding between waypoints.. isn't it feasible to use A* "freely" between them, too, i.e. letting each waypoint could point to much more than just two other waypoints?
(12:44:43)<Kadwiell>(I.e. with only the waypoints as vertices.. thus still much "coarser" and faster than A* over every cell)
(01:04:22)<RotateMe_away>not sure i understand what you mean...
(01:04:44)<RotateMe_away>to just use waypoints instead of a*?
(01:05:44)<Perdurabo>evening
(01:09:47)<RotateMe>hi
(01:27:13)<Kadwiell>Well, I'm not sure I understood what you were doing.. but if you are using very few potential "next waypoints" from each waypoint, I think there's a possibility of weirdness
(01:27:36)<Kadwiell>Not that I can think of an example at the moment
(01:32:33)<RotateMe>there's only one next waypoint from each waypoint
(01:33:04)<RotateMe>this is because it's more of a strategy game like map with two camps on each side
(01:33:24)<RotateMe>waypoints connect those camps and units only move from their camp to the enemy
(01:34:00)<RotateMe>but like i said, i'm adding forks, which just makes waypoints randomly show one of all possible next waypoints to the unit
(01:37:27)<Kadwiell>Hmm, okay
(01:38:27)<Kadwiell>My idea was to use standard pathfinding (e.g. A*) on an "abstract" scale, that is, just between the waypoints (with costs and paths precalculated)
(01:39:08)<Kadwiell>Would be more flexible, but a little more expensive, so if your design doesn't call for it I guess it's not necessary
(01:43:14)<RotateMe>wouldn't it be vice versa?
(01:44:15)<RotateMe>less expensive because there are less waypoints than squares but less flexible for the same reason?
(01:44:34)<RotateMe>but it's a good idea in general
(01:45:21)<RotateMe>problem is, it's often hard to assure that one waypoint after the other can be reached without any pathfinding neccassery
(01:45:33)<RotateMe>depends of how complex your dungeons are i guess
(01:45:54)<RotateMe>gotta go now though, cu

(01:31:40)<Grisnak>i noticed some "..." parts in the code
(01:31:45)<Grisnak>what is that all about?
(01:31:55)<Grisnak>TCODConsole::printLeft(int x, int y, TCOD_bkgnd_flag_t flag, const char *fmt, ...)
(01:31:57)<Grisnak>like that
(01:32:32)<Grisnak>is that what Im going to be drawing to the screen?
(01:32:44)<RotateMe>well, kind of
(01:33:00)<RotateMe>the 'const char *fmt' is a format string
(01:33:11)<RotateMe>that means it can either be a normal string, like "hello world"
(01:33:25)<RotateMe>or it can be something like "hp: %d/%d"
(01:33:38)<Grisnak>ok
(01:33:38)<Grisnak>so
(01:33:48)<RotateMe>those two "%d"'s point to two ints that will follow
(01:33:51)<Grisnak>would I replace that const char with what I want to display?
(01:34:13)<Grisnak>Like Im attempting to draw to the screen "Welcome to my game"
(01:34:17)<Grisnak>in the game window
(01:34:30)<Grisnak>Ive mainly been doing console applications
(01:34:35)<RotateMe>so eg:    TCODConsole::printLeft(0,0,TCOD_BKGND_NONE,"HP: %d/%d",playerHP,playerMaxHP);
(01:34:36)<Grisnak>so the cout << "blah" works
(01:34:54)<Grisnak>Ok
(01:34:57)<Grisnak>lemme mess with this
(01:34:58)<Grisnak>hehe
(01:35:06)<RotateMe>this would draw something like 'HP: 5/10' at the top left corner of the screen
(01:35:23)<RotateMe>%d is for ints, %f is for floats and %s is for string as far as i can remember
(01:35:53)<RotateMe>but just lookup printf() on any reference website, there you will find an explanation about format strings
(01:36:23)<Grisnak>oh ok
(01:36:36)<RotateMe>btw, i always use TCOD_BGKND_NONE, never had a use for the others and i guess it's pretty much what you will want to use for what you're doing
(01:37:37)<RotateMe>x is the x coordinate how you know it from school, but y in programming in most cases refers to the distance from the top of the screen
(01:37:47)<RotateMe>so 0 is the top row
(01:37:59)<Grisnak>yeah
(01:39:53)<Grisnak>TCODConsole::printLeft(0, 0, TCOD_BKGND_NONE, "%s", welcome);
(01:39:55)<Grisnak>ok so that
(01:40:02)<Grisnak>would print on the left side of the screen
(01:40:04)<Grisnak>what I want it to right?
(01:40:21)<Grisnak>Cause I get a stupid error trying to compile it

(03:04:10)<eMetatoR>okay... well, explanation: string is not one of the basic data types in c/c++, string is a "wrapper" for an array of chars (single letters assembled together)
(03:04:26)<eMetatoR>"%s" seems to be calling for such a char*
(03:04:44)<eMetatoR>string has a method that returns such a char* called c_str()
(03:04:51)<Grisnak>Ahhhhhhhhhhh
(03:05:08)<eMetatoR>but don't ask me why it worked for me

(10:36:50)<deveah>found yer roguelike language
(10:36:51)<deveah>'A language based on a roguelike game such as NetHack. The language would be non-deterministic, since roguelikes are traditionally very random. "Programs" would be represented as a player - the interpreter would act as a bot going through the dungeon, functions would be learnable skills, and data would be treasure and junk found in the dungeon. Since permadeath is a feature of roguelikes, there is no guarantee that a program will succeed in executing, althou
(10:36:51)<deveah>ES succeed in execution, it would be guaranteed to produce an accurate result. To make things more difficult the program could only produce the appropriate result after successfully obtaining some artifact (e.g. The Executor) and leaving the dungeon.--wildhalcyon 14:44, 25 July 2007 (UTC)
(10:37:11)<deveah>http://esolangs.org/wiki/List_of_ideas it's on that page

(10:56:59)<deveah>it is :)

(06:43:00)<deveah>i wrote a simple Brainfuck-like language interpreter in 20 mins
(06:43:04)<deveah>Binplus
(06:43:15)<deveah>-x switch to var x (a-z)
(06:43:15)<deveah>01 increment by 1
(06:43:15)<deveah>00 decrement by 1
(06:43:15)<deveah>1x jumps x positions (a-z)
(06:43:15)<deveah>1- output as char
(06:43:16)<deveah>-1 output as integer
(06:43:18)<deveah>0- loop start (loops until the var is 0)
(06:43:20)<deveah>-0 loop end   (loops until the var is 0)
(06:43:22)<deveah>-- store user input
(06:45:51)<deveah>works pretty well

(08:31:16)<TMC2>so, in P1[c1] or not P2[x1]
(08:31:29)<TMC2>is x1 unbound?
(08:31:37)<joe6pack>yes
(08:31:47)<joe6pack>x's are variables 
(08:31:54)<joe6pack>c's constants]
(08:31:57)<joe6pack>f's dunctions
(08:32:01)<joe6pack>*functions
(08:32:14)<joe6pack>i didn't use functions in my example but you can use them
(08:32:24)<joe6pack>and P's predicates 
(08:32:40)<TMC2>so does that mean P1[c1] or not P2[x1] for some x1?
(08:32:56)<joe6pack>for all x1
(08:33:11)<joe6pack>when no quantifier is given "all" is assumed 
(08:33:20)<TMC2>ah, confusing
(08:33:32)<joe6pack>if you want some you have to write exists[x1] at the beginning 
(08:33:56)<joe6pack>the example is trivial, it has no meaning
(08:34:00)<joe6pack>i just used it for testing
(08:34:37)<joe6pack>see how there is the "all[x1]" quantifier at the 1st line?
(08:34:47)<joe6pack>you can use exist in the same way
(08:36:43)<TMC2>and the conclusion is 'not P2[c1]' ?
(08:36:53)<joe6pack>yea
(08:37:03)<joe6pack>i need to improve the interface a bit
(08:37:18)<joe6pack>i just finished coding it yesterday and only worked on the logic

(08:38:56)<joe6pack>next time i work on it

(08:40:02)<joe6pack>oh i use them for everything
